reviewText:
Short version:
This is the best zombie themed game I've ever played. If you are looking for a good zombie game, stop now and buy this game. Enemy variety, tons of weapons, fantastic platforming, solid combat, great horror elements, at least 50+ hours of content. 9.5/10. Buy this game!

Long Version:
I have to give credit to the developers of Dying Light. In today's era of everyone complaining about nothing being original and developers mainly trying to fulfill these complaints, the developers of DL knew what we REALLY wanted. A solid game that takes the best of many other games and fuses them into one.

The core gameplay is a FPS platformer much like Mirror's Edge, but with a refined system allowing you to climb on basically anything. As a general rule in this game, if you can see it, you can go to it. This alone makes the otherwise normal-sized map MUCH larger than it appears, adding lots of depth to exploration. Later into the game, a grappling hook mechanic is introduced, which will make you feel like Spiderman, zipping around the map with ease.

The combat is extremely solid and mainly revolves around melee. I feel this is a much more accurate representation of a zombie outbreak when compared to titles like Left 4 Dead (no running around with machine guns with near-infinite ammo). Guns are rare but powerful, and handle well in combat. In this sense, the combat resembles Dead Island a lot, but feels more refined to me.

The item system is based off a color-coded rarity mechanic similiar to that found in games like Borderlands, which allows you to know if a weapon/item is worth picking up at a glance. On top of this, weapons can be upgraded and modified, adding an extra layer of depth and customizability. Most weapons fit into 3 groups: One handed, two handed, and guns (guns cannot be modified).

This game also involves heavy RPG elements reminiscent of Tomb Raider, with 3 seperate skill trees devoted to parkour, combat, and quests. Characters won't necessarily be unique, as at the higher levels, all skills can be purchased, but this definitely adds more depth to an already massively deep game.

The story is fairly generic, with nothing really shocking or surprising. This is to be expected though, as the zombie outbreak story can only be done so many ways without becoming ridiculous (looking at you, resident evil). As referenced by the title of the game, the story involves the now-familiar 'zombies are more aggressive at night' idea. In addition, special 'volatile' zombies appear, which are extremely deadly and will chase the player around, adding an element of horror to this. The player is encouraged to brave the night with special bonuses to XP occurring only at night, and certain missions only completable at night.

It goes without saying that the graphics are georgous, as this is definitely a next-gen game in that sense. The visuals are solid and consistant, with a full day/night cycle, weather effects, fancy-but-not-intrusive film and blur effects, etc. The sound is fantastic, adding to the overall theme of the game, and definitely contributing to the horror at night.

The 4-player co-op works great, little to no lag, and is very fun. Only issues I've had are some microphone issues, but are relatively minor. The multiplayer PvP is a little odd but not bad. I don't have much experience with this mode so can't comment much on that.

I was extremely surprised at the level of polish and depth in this game, with only tiny little nitpicks here and there. It is very apparent that the developers looked at successful mechanics in popular games (Mirror's Edge, Borderlands, Tomb Raider, Dead Island, etc) and integrated similiar mechanics into their design, resulting in a game that feels completely rounded. This game flew under my radar when it first released, and I received it as a gift for christmas 2015 and started playing it with no prior knowledge. This game really deserves all the praise I could pour on it, and more people should check this out.

If you like zombie games, you will love this game. 9.5/10

reviewText:
A stereotypical zombie survival - Think again.

This game is fantastic, a odd mix of parkour and zombies that goes especially well together. It's not only zombies there are gangs, mutant running things and huge tough ones. The gear in the game is really brilliant, there's just so many different items, craft parts and other upgrades. You want a katana that electrocutes, poisons and burns zombies? you got one! This really helps the game in becoming very atmospheric, with a constant spooky feel you never feel safe, even when you're in a safe zone. The game is also very well balanced, to start off it;s hard and as you move along it's also hard: only at the end of the following do the zombies seem to get easier.

The game runs perfectly, I'm on a GTX 960 and an i5 at the moment, running at a constant 60+ FPS. The game has never crashed once and I've experianced literally no bugs. The only problem is when things get cluttered up with hordes of zombies, although this is VERY infrequent.

In conclusion this game is amazing, fast paced and fluid action combined with the huge amounts of variety in weapons makes for a very sucessful game, which is a must for any survival, parkour or zombie fans!

reviewText:
Heads up, game fans! It's time to review the new zombie apocalypse game that so many people are playing and talking about: Dying Light. I've had a taste, and I want more, but will you? Read along and hopefully find out. I'm not going to tell you everything, and I'm trying to avoid any serious spoilers, but I will give you just a taste so that you can judge for yourself. Please keep in mind that this review is current as of the date of publication, but I have no idea what features may change, improve or get nerfed after this point. I am not including in this review aspects of the DLC, but I may review that later. Or not.

If I had to give just a brief idea of what this game is like, take a little bit of Fallout 3, just the tiniest taste of Crysis, a dash of Skyrim, a sprinkling of Far Cry 2, a little more FC2, toss in some inspiration from L4D2, and then top it all off with some Mirror's Edge, and you might get an idea of what this game is like. Maybe. Also throw in some optional asymmetrical fps with some rather unfortunate choices on the part of the developer to get even closer to the full experience.

You start off parachuting into a situation in a quarantined city somewhere seemingly in the Middle East. You have to find that one guy that your organization needs you to find; you know the one. You get infected, and you need medicine. That's how you're compromised, and that's how you begin working your way into the local sitch. You make yourself at home and begin doing odd jobs to improve your standing, gather intel, and make reports back to the peeps in charge in the rear. You can probably guess where this is going, so that's all I'm going to say about the back story. If you don't get medicine regularly, you get sicker and could possibly turn. So far it hasn't affected my gameplay as much as the same mechanic that was used in Far Cry 2, but I haven't gone very far in the main story line either. In the relatively brief time I've played this game, I've only had convulsions the one time.

You spend all your time climbing, running, jumping, ducking, dodging, and generally trying to outmaneuver, overpower, or out-think your opponents. You constantly have to think about where you're going next and how. The game has freedom, but with it also comes a terrible price. Sometimes you choose wrong, and it hurts so bad when you do. Conversely, when you choose well, and it works, it feels really good, too.

You get three skill trees, each with a different focus--one for gear, one for agility, and one for power. The things you do build your skills in the respective area, and if you want to get better at something, try doing it repeatedly or things closely related to it. Craft items and you'll be able to craft more items. Take on zombies one on one in melee, and you'll get better at it. Try extreme stunts, and you'll become a world-class parkour... -er (actually, the proper term is traceur" if you didn't know... I didn't).

Your opponents are a blend of frightening zeds with some specials mixed in who will not always stand out at a distance the way they will in L4D2. Once you know what you're looking for they will be all too apparent in most cases

reviewText:
I Finished Dying Light today and while I loved it for the first few days of playing, I can honestly say I was biterly disappointed by the end. And I dont just mean the end of the game, I mean the end of my time with it, lets say from about 50% onwards.

Following is a long and I hope thorough review of the game. I could go on for many more pages than I will here because there is much to talk about but I will try and focus on major points as much as I can..

Please remember, this is my opinion, some folks will agree with me, some won't, but dont flame for flames sake. Try and keep it decent, I like a good reply as much as this review

So whats right with it? Well, in the beginning you feel part of something, you have a direction and a reason for being. You make some friends, and while the storyline is not the greatest, the acting and general pacing are good, engaging and you feel like you actually want to help, to succeed.

Finding out about the games many mechanics is immensely fun, from your first parkour lessons, to learning to electricute  zombies with fallen powr lines and puddles is all very satisfying. Killing the zombies themselves is satisfying, and I can honestly say that for the first 3 or 4 days (around 4-6 hours each) I rated Dying Light as one of the very best zombie killing experiences.

The skill system is clever, varied, and most of the skills are actually fun to learn, allowing you to develop a 'style' of play.

One of my absolute favourite things about Dying Light is how much havoc it lets you cause by giving you as many materials as you could possibly need to craft the games many different zombie killing utilities. You are never short of anything, and I really believe that more open world games shoudl be this way. Sure, make a player search for these things but dont make them rare as rocking horse ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•... The more you allow a player to make molotovs, the more he will use them and have infinite fun doing so!! Well done on this devs of Dying Lght, a great great choice!

Your first time at night is VERY memorable, (as are many of the other times, but that first is the charm) and doing every side quest feels fun and somehow non repetitive. The miriad of ways you learn to kill a zombie keeps the game fresh for a long while.

Around 50% however the game for me began to sour... (spoilers from here - if your undecided and dont want to read the rest of the review because of the spoilers know that I do recommend the game, if only for the first 30 hours or so, its well worth the asking price. if you like killin zombies enmasse ten buy yourself a copy!)

Ok so for those that stuck around.

At first it wasn't very noticeable because the variety was still there but as you progress in the game you begin to notice just how much the zombies seem to take the same amount of killing no matter what weapons you use... This 'leveled creature' way of making games always leaves me scratching my head. I simply cant understand why developers make games that level with you? All this does is make 'upgrading' utterly pointless. (well other than you will die horrendously if you dont!)
I had weapons in my inventory that did 200 damage, 300 damage and 400 damage. Each of these weapons (if aimed right) took 1 or 2 hits to kill each zombie. So whats the point of finding and making 'better' weapons if you never see any real improvement in them because the zombies level with you?? For god sake devs of today.. Learn this does not make a game fun! Whats FUN, is when you can return to an earlier place in the game and wipe everything out with a single swing! Thats the feeling of 'progression' which simply dies with leveled creatures!

Ok, ok, so open world has to deal with this ability to go anywhere at anytime somehow.. Is leveling the creatures the way to do it? NO!! Put tougher creatures in in other areas.. Make it impossible for  new player to traverse certain areas until they 'progress' the reason we all play - progression.

Anyway, you get my point, this game is bad for it!

This game is also bad for changing the rules on you. At first you are very scared of the virals, these are newly turned zombies who still have all their motor skills intact. They can run, they can climb, they are not stupid and mindless... They are scary!

At first.

The rules change around the 50% mark again, and rather than 'noise' bringing them, they just seem to be everywhere, and come whenever they want to. Curiously around this time the other zombies seem to now explode after dying, sending toxic goo all around that hurts you if you get caught in it. This 'explosion' is the catalyst for bringing more virals! Sorry, but his is DUMB! Why change the rules!? If they player makes noise, expect company, this is a great mechanic, fun to think 'oh ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•' I made loads of noise! But creating excuses for them to be there is poor, and a seemingly lazy way to make the game harder.

Then comes the introduction of the harder zombies, the ones with big heafty weapons they smash on the floor creating shockwaves that send you flying! These guys are slow, but tough! Early on, its virtually impossible to take them out without a lot of running in and getting a hit here and there. Later they become utterly ridiculous in difficulty and just there to make the game harder. Not 'tactical', just harder for the sake of it. Again this feels like a half ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• attept at making the game harder...

Dont even get me started on the exploders!! They hide around corners, and even lightning reflexes wont turn you quick enough to get out of their explosion range. I wonder sometimes what Playtesters do all day.. because they obviously dont provide decent feedback.

Now before someone starts flaming me here about wanting the game made easier.. NO I DONT. This is not about making anything easier, its about being more clever in the first place with what your creatures can and cant do. Make them scary by all means, make them tough as nails, but dont make it frustrating, like the fights are here in dying light.

It feels i'm getting on a bit of a downer with the game here and please understad that I did enjoy it, I just get tired with the same old same old type of development. Keep games fun, fair, and exciting... Dont set out to ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• off your player base.

So what did I not like...

The halucination sequence with Jade.. Honestly!! Who thought that was a good idea!! It was CRAP!

The tower climbing... Kinda on the fence about this because the controls worked well, and it was satisfying but death was often just annoying, and  paths were blocked often just for the sake of it.

Leading on from that, even the games hero starts to shout phrases such as 'Oh you gotta be ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing kidding me!!' because even HE is fed up with the way the game just seems to want to '‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• with you' The cable snapping in the radio tower?? Why did it snap? Whats the reasoning behind this??

As the story developed I felt it got more and more ridiculous, there were times I wished for the feel of the beginning of the game, where things had passion, and made you feel something. But when you find yourself at the finale running through sewers being chased by everything the game has, where one slip-up (which was often as simpe as a 'clip' by a creature) would send you plumiting to your death, you feel less and less attached to the game, and more that it IS a game, one you want over... The restarting of this sequence with every death by the way was a hideous development choice!

Then the last fight with our buddy Rise... timed key pressing, Really?? This is a developers idea of a good ending? Simply horrendous. One of the worst endings I have ever played I am sad to say.

So, here we are.. TL:DR

It has enough greatness to make it a fantastic experience. It is however marred by some horrendous development choices and a story that by half way you no longer care about. (which is a shame)

8/10 for me..

reviewText:
Man, I really can't formulate my thoughts right now -- this was *exactly* the game I was waiting for a really, really long time.

Okay, first of all -- so much props to Techland for stepping up and making everything they have planned, and so much more.

Dying Light is easily the best sandbox zombie FPS out there, and the best AAA game of 2015 (already, yeah). Techland outdid themselves with this one -- you can consider Dying Light a perfected version of Dead Island (the first sandbox zombie FPS, I think). Graphics, sounds, music, atmosphere, script -- everything was perfected, and released with practically no delays (something for Ubisoft to learn here).

If you don't know what to expect from the game, watch the E3 trailer -- the game is *exactly* like the trailer. Which is so hard to believe, actually, isn't it? Well, trust me: I've tried everything they were doing in the trailer -- and it works perfectly: throwing zombies, setting traps, jump-kicking, throwing weapons, running through your course of traps from infected, looking back at them, setting off your traps...

reviewText:
Well I just finished the game and it was quite a ride.  One of my biggest complaints about most zombie based games is that the stories are usually pretty weak, and a lot of this has to do to the necessity for co-op experiences. Dying Light has one of the best single player campaigns (although you can certainly play co-op) I have ever played and much of that is you become Kyle Crane, a GRE operative tasked with recovering a stolen file regarding the viral outbreak in Harran.  The main missions guide you through quite a few individual missions, each one advancing the story. The story is quite good as you keep wanting to see more but you also have a plethora of side missions helping other survivors in many different ways. The mission design for both main and side missions is so varied that I don't think any really felt the same.  And best yet, you really feel like you are helping the survivors when you complete these missions, as many of them sound like realistic requests during a fragile fight for survival.

The comparisons of a cross between Dead Island and Mirror's Edge is not far off.  The parkour elements really shine in this game, and as you level up your agility you get access to more and more abilities that make you even better. It's quite a rush to run full flight jumping from rooftop to rooftop, executing quick climb and jump moves, and sliding under low hanging obstacles.  The combat feels very much like Dead Island with a crafting system and modification system very similar. You must collect blueprints to expand your crafting and modification options; many become available as you spend survival points (which is mostly gained by completing missions or returning supply drops), or by finding blueprints in the world or by completing side missions or protection missions.  Your combat ability is handled via power points, which are gained by hitting infected and killing them in a myriad of ways. Spending power points gives you access to different combat abilities like power swing, whirlwind with two-handed weapons, and death from above which impales an enemy when you are above them.

During daytime the game can be challenging as there are a lot of different special infected much like Dead Island. Come nighttime though, and all bets are off.  The game becomes more of a stealth game as you try to avoid volatiles, the most powerful infected in the game.  Early on you have no chance of killing one of these but as you reach higher levels and get access to better weapons with super modifications you can end up killing them in one power swing. The problem is, attacking a volatile or being seen by one immediately alerts every other volatile in the immediate vicinity. The speed that these volatiles close in on you and pummel you to death is astonishing. You may wonder why bother playing during the night as you can just sleep at any safehouse until the morning. Some missions require you to do them at night like the early one where you have to restore the full power grid at three substations. The other reason is all power and agility xp is doubled at night, which really makes a difference as I found agility to be lagging behind survivor and power xp.  Also, the longer you survive at night the more bonus survivor points you will get once morning comes. I found I rarely ended up sleeping until morning, preferring to maneuver myself to specific locations by jumping between safehouses, trying to stay unnoticed by the volatiles but occasionally alerting them and booking it while throwing UV flares to slow the pursuit down.

Overall, this was a fantastic game that was so fun it was hard to put down.  There are a few framerate issues where the FPS would drop to the single digits for 10-15 seconds until eventually clearing up. The graphics are gorgeous, the animations fluid, and the gameplay top-notch.  The game works well with both keyboard/mouse and gamepad. I played with a gamepad mostly because 90% of the time you are fighting with melee weapons and I like the feel of the gamepad in that manner. If you like action/adventure games with good stories, a plethora of gameplay options, and the freedom to do what you want in the order you want, then I highly recommend this game. It's worth it at full price.

reviewText:
Dying Light is a first rate, first person game in an apocalyptic city overrun with zombies. The variety of melee weapons and monsters, along with some genuinely creepy settings (repeatable quests are spooky!), make this one a real winner. The distinctive of DL, besides it's quality of production, is the addition of massive quantities of parkour. As a rule, I don't like jumping games, and I never got totally great at it in DL, but there are some acrophobic thrills in this game that'll make your blood run cold. I don't know if any other game has tempted my fear of heights like this one. Your capacity to climb and leap is superhuman, but not fantastically so. The only place parjour really annoyed me was on the cliffs. I realize the developers may have wanted to create some limits and bottlenecks, but it is frustrating to have your parkour, and grapple, simply not work sometimes because you're not supposed to go over this particular cliff rock here...

More serious than the Dead Rising series, DL does have crafting, but you won't find any electrified rakes here. You also, although heroic and epic often, you will not be plowing down hundreds of zeds at a time. Taking on a stack of 10 will require maneuver and savvy, even with a good weapon. In a standard of the genre, one on one they are weak -- but in packs, can be dangerous. (Not to mention the really big ones.) The story is deep, more serious than many other zombie first person games, and you may find yourself caring about some of your NPC colleagues, although -- for an open world situation -- you are limited in how you can engage them. The dialogs are story driven, so you won't be getting married, bringing allies with you into battle, etc. This is not zombie Skyrim.

The difficulty curve is somewhat steep as you get started, with the early weapons lame enough you'll find yourself tapping on a single zed many times before they fall over. If you've got friends who are able to give you some good weapons early, it will change the difficulty dramatically. Get a weapon that does several hundred damage, you'll see slo-mo swaths as you cleave a zed, or multiple zeds, in every stroke with pieces flying in multiple directions. In DL, as your survivor score goes up, the (melee) weapons you find do also. One of the really nice features is when someone opens a box or vehicle in this game, every member of the party gets to draw something out.

The boss fights in DL are not great, but there aren't a bunch of them -- by far the majority of the action is within the normal systems of the game, which are excellent. But, as off tactic as some of the boss fights are, I did find myself caring about what happened in them. That shows the effectiveness of the story, the dialogs, the characterizations, and the settings.

In summary, if you like zombies, this is a can't miss. I'm still waiting for the day I can play a PC zombie game where you can recruit friends and allies, build realistic forts, and build resources for a community. But, DL does the low intensity thing very well, and the parkour thing was an unexpected add-on for this genre. This game will have you holding your breath sometimes, as when you face a Demolisher, or get caught out at night, or run out of med kits, or scale the side of the bridge. Those thrills are authentic and a credit to the game and the genre. DL also allows you to mow down a lot of zeds and feel proud of yourself. Enjoy!

The sound in this game is sure to immerse you as the undead growl from a distance, each melee connects with a satisfying crunch, the slight sound of wind as you parkour your way up rooftops and through safe zones, and quite frankly I enjoyed the sound immensely.  This is all backed up with a pretty good story.  I actually had a motivation to continue with the story and did very few side quests throughout my time with it. The conclusion to the game was more or less satisfying, as what you expected to be an epic boss battle turned out to be a quick time event.  As to avoid spoilers, thats all I have to say about that.  Now the gameplay.  This game has extremely addicting melee combat.  It does start off slow with the weak weapons and the whole take-8-hits-to-take-out-a-single-zombie-for-the-first-4-hours bit, but once you get going the game gives you a great sense of progression.  You'll start seeing zombies being dispatched more quickly, an abundance of arms flying to your left and right, and finish each fight off with a well-placed swing to the neck and watch the heads roll.  There's a variety of weapons, whether your busting heads into pieces with pipes or sledgehammers or simply decapitating the undead with a sickle or a machete.  The ragdoll physics are quite entertaining, too.  I found myself dropkicking a LOT of zombies off of rooftops because its just so enjoyable to watch them spin and distort themselves before inevitably landing headfirst into the concrete 50 feet below, leaving chunks of brain spewing all around them.  Another core element of gameplay is the parkour.  People have referred to this game as Mirror's Edge+ Dead Island, and for good reason.  Navigating the rooftops is a breeze and I've only had a few moments where I couldn't climb a wall I previously thought was possible to scale.  You can jump quite far, too. reviewText:
This is the first review of a game I've done on Steam. These days due to personal time constraints and other interests, it seems as though I finish very few games - especially open world ones like Dying Light. In open world games, I always get distracted by side missions and over time I lose interest in the story and move on to some other game. However, Dying Light kept my interest the entire time! I cannot place my finger on it, but this game was unique and absolutely engrossing for me. I'll probably go back in and finish the side missions I didn't complete before finishing the main story.

I RARELY went out at night unless a mission required it. I'm so glad a fast travel system was not included. It was interesting to see myself react when I knew night was coming and I was a distance from a safe house. The game is not full of jump scares like Alien: Isolation (a game I wanted to love but hated - the problem was me...not the game).

I have not played multiplayer or done any of the challenges so I cannot comment on that. I simply did the story and many side missions.

I cannot recommend this game enough!

Dying Light may be yet another zombie game in a glutted genre, but its Mirror's Edge-esque parkour and fast paced melee combat really make its stand out among the pack and it is actually quite fun. The game is actually quite tense at night too and has shades of survival horror. The missions are fun enough and don't feel repetitive as well. The writing is actually fairly solid for an action game, mainly in the sidequests. and it doesn't take itself too seriously and Crane is a likable protagonist to separate him enough from the usual AAA game white dude protagonist. It's also very pretty. The parkour mostly feels smooth but precision platforming feels janky, especially because you can‚Äôt easily drop down. (Unless I just don‚Äôt know how to do it.) The exploding zombies are also utter ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•t, the challenges are absolutely ridiculous (To the point where I don't think they playtested them at all, or if they did it was by video game savants) and the endgame kind of craps itself but it doesn't drag it down too much. Overall Dying Light is a modern zombie action game done right and definitely worth playing if you‚Äôre interested.

reviewText:
Why. The hell. Do games insist. In QTE. Final boss fights?

The combat was great, the movement was great, the weapons felt great.
Final confrontation? Everything taken away, the gameplay, the movement, the weapons, the cover, the terrain.

The damn QTE prompts didn't change and were so damn sudden and expired so quick that it turned into a freaking SIMON emulator.

Story? Rather predictable, even for a zombie apocalypse.

Now, all that aside, everything between the tutorial and the final boss was thoroughly enjoyable, save for the clever invader that was just too damn hard to kill.
--Side note. I will never understand who thought it would be a good idea to give someone a one-hit-kill attack and an invulnerability shield...

Final word.
I challenge you to find a zombie on a cliff and not laugh as you dropkick it down the side.

reviewText:
Dying Light is a first rate, first person game in an apocalyptic city overrun with zombies. The variety of melee weapons and monsters, along with some genuinely creepy settings (repeatable quests are spooky!), make this one a real winner. The distinctive of DL, besides it's quality of production, is the addition of massive quantities of parkour. As a rule, I don't like jumping games, and I never got totally great at it in DL, but there are some acrophobic thrills in this game that'll make your blood run cold. I don't know if any other game has tempted my fear of heights like this one. Your capacity to climb and leap is superhuman, but not fantastically so. The only place parjour really annoyed me was on the cliffs. I realize the developers may have wanted to create some limits and bottlenecks, but it is frustrating to have your parkour, and grapple, simply not work sometimes because you're not supposed to go over this particular cliff rock here...

More serious than the Dead Rising series, DL does have crafting, but you won't find any electrified rakes here. You also, although heroic and epic often, you will not be plowing down hundreds of zeds at a time. Taking on a stack of 10 will require maneuver and savvy, even with a good weapon. In a standard of the genre, one on one they are weak -- but in packs, can be dangerous. (Not to mention the really big ones.) The story is deep, more serious than many other zombie first person games, and you may find yourself caring about some of your NPC colleagues, although -- for an open world situation -- you are limited in how you can engage them. The dialogs are story driven, so you won't be getting married, bringing allies with you into battle, etc. This is not zombie Skyrim.

The difficulty curve is somewhat steep as you get started, with the early weapons lame enough you'll find yourself tapping on a single zed many times before they fall over. If you've got friends who are able to give you some good weapons early, it will change the difficulty dramatically. Get a weapon that does several hundred damage, you'll see slo-mo swaths as you cleave a zed, or multiple zeds, in every stroke with pieces flying in multiple directions. In DL, as your survivor score goes up, the (melee) weapons you find do also. One of the really nice features is when someone opens a box or vehicle in this game, every member of the party gets to draw something out.

The boss fights in DL are not great, but there aren't a bunch of them -- by far the majority of the action is within the normal systems of the game, which are excellent. But, as off tactic as some of the boss fights are, I did find myself caring about what happened in them. That shows the effectiveness of the story, the dialogs, the characterizations, and the settings.

In summary, if you like zombies, this is a can't miss. I'm still waiting for the day I can play a PC zombie game where you can recruit friends and allies, build realistic forts, and build resources for a community. But, DL does the low intensity thing very well, and the parkour thing was an unexpected add-on for this genre. This game will have you holding your breath sometimes, as when you face a Demolisher, or get caught out at night, or run out of med kits, or scale the side of the bridge. Those thrills are authentic and a credit to the game and the genre. DL also allows you to mow down a lot of zeds and feel proud of yourself. Enjoy!

reviewText:
This is the first review of a game I've done on Steam. These days due to personal time constraints and other interests, it seems as though I finish very few games - especially open world ones like Dying Light. In open world games, I always get distracted by side missions and over time I lose interest in the story and move on to some other game. However, Dying Light kept my interest the entire time! I cannot place my finger on it, but this game was unique and absolutely engrossing for me. I'll probably go back in and finish the side missions I didn't complete before finishing the main story.

I RARELY went out at night unless a mission required it. I'm so glad a fast travel system was not included. It was interesting to see myself react when I knew night was coming and I was a distance from a safe house. The game is not full of jump scares like Alien: Isolation (a game I wanted to love but hated - the problem was me...not the game).

I have not played multiplayer or done any of the challenges so I cannot comment on that. I simply did the story and many side missions.

I cannot recommend this game enough!

There is one word that best descibes Dying Light:  density.  Dying Light takes everything great from Dead Island and massively improves on it.

At first glance, upon being let loose in the sandbox that is Dying Light, you may think the map is small.  I know that was my first impression.  As you explore the city and further the story, you find out just how large the map truly is.  About halfway through the main story line, you will open up another large city area.  The word density truly takes on meaning when you begin exploring this location.  The game opens up more and more locations, including challenge areas (sort of like dungeons in Skyrim) as the game progresses.  Interior locations are numerous, almost mind boggling at times, especially in Old Town.  There are sewers to explore as well.  Transition areas and hidden caverns also help to increase exploration time.  Old Town is really 3 maps stacked on top of each other as there are layers and layers of places to explore.  The Following expansion provides another area to explore, even larger than the main game.

And explore you shall.  If you played Dead Island you remember how many times you had to loot that hard shell suitcase, which came in different colors to spice things up." This became incredibly stale as your eyes became used to scanning for that same container

reviewText:
Dying Light plus The Following (expansion) are what Dead Island and it's expansion promised to be but didn't. Techland managed to keep what little good features Dead Island had and improve them by bringing them over to the spiritual successor. Before I go into the endless bashing of Dead Island (the premise is nice but the execution was awful), lets stick to what makes Dying Light a great zombie game.

Unlike you run of the mill zombie games, Dying Light regular zombies are not your average slow-moving-arm-flailing-brain-hungry humanoids, wanting nothing more than to land on your bullets or melee weapons. They are scary, they are numerous and they will try to kill you. Their most important quality is numbers however. They'll plentiful and since weapons degrade and guns create noise which will attract the improved Virals (think of 28 days later fast zombies) , going into a square with 100 of them is not the best of ideas.

Dying Light creates a very good atmosphere where you're not just a guns blazing supersoldier going on a bloody rampage against them. You're a survivor and you need to survive. That means getting resources, spending them wisely, sleeping the night off or even fight through the night for some extra XP. The game manages to convey the feeling of helplessness into the player in a beautiful tone.There's a variety of special enemies, the most formidable being the so called Volatiles, disfigured monsters of the night who will chase you relentlessly throughout Harran (the city in which the vanilla game takes place).

The game's strongpoint is the parkour mechanics. Future games will most likely begin to incorporate this new feature and nothing would be better than game developers taking notes on how Dying Light manages the freerunning mechanics. It's super easy to learn, to control, very responsive to your actions, and adds a brilliant way to make perfect use of your environment. I've played game with freerunning mechanics and nothing comes close to Dying Light's system.
Admittedly the grappling hook gets little buggy sometimes, but it's a small price to pay for an otherwise excellent system. Every rooftop, every lamp-post, even corner of the building can be your haven, your battlefield or your grave. Absolutely astounding and it carries over into the Following as well although in a much less degree due to the vehicle mechanics.

The game features an XP system, in 3 categories (5 with the Enhanced Edition/The Following), which include your fighting skill, your survival and your agility (running&climbing). XP is earned by doing quests (the game features a lot of sidequests with their own mini arcs and characters, ranging from being a little bit on the funny side, to some being just depressing), killing enemies, running and climbing buildings and collecting resources from airdrops. The day/night feature of the game, allows you to get double XP during night, however during night the Volatiles will appears to make your life a living hell.

However Dying Light is not without its faults. Guns feel pretty weak and are very limited (vanilla game) however in The Following they were improved dramatically, doing more damage and having more guns to choose from. If you plan on playing Multiplayer co-op with friends, be adviced that the final mission of the game can only be played solo. Why was that a thing? Completely pointless, I mean I can sorf of understand due to the reason that the ending of the game fall unfortunately into the dreadful category of QTE(quick time events). Why oh why did you ruin an otherwise good story, with a QTE near the end I'll never understand. And of course, if you're playing with friends, you better disconnect and finish the game on your own, cause the game won't allow you to do it with friends. Big disappointment.


The Following is the sequel of the story of the original game. You play in the outskirt farmlands of Harran, where you meet a different set characters. The most important feature is the addition of a the buggy.
The buggy feels a little bit... of foreign agent in the Dying Light world. You do less parkour and use it for transportation since The Following takes place in open rural area with few buildings. Not to say that there isn't freerunning in The Following, but is much less than the vanilla game.
The Following adds two more extra trees to gain XP in, driving and Legend levels. Driving can be maxed very easily and very quickly just by running enemies over and the Legend levels include passive bonuses on your characters.
Don't get me wrong, the Following a pretty good addition to the game, adds around 20-30 hours of gameplay and it's definitely worth its money.

At the same time however, some of the characters feel more shallow than the ones in the vanilla game but the worst offender is the story of the game and it's absurd ending. No spoilers but the ending was bad. Like really bad. Mass Effect 3 bad. And of course you cannot finish it in a Multiplayer session with friends. You gotta do it solo. Again.
There's no real villain in the Following. The story feels rushed, some things are unexplained or just make no sense with the story of the game and the ending features a deus ex machina which has no real connection to anything you'll encounter in the vanilla game and the expansion.


Long story short: Dying Light: The Following - Enhanced Edition is well worth its money and its a definite recommendation for people who feel a little bit of zombie-game fatigue". It's mechanics are greats

reviewText:
Hi all.
First I wanted to warn you that this is one of my first reviews :). All what I write here is MY feels on the game. By the way sorry for my english, I'm from Poland :D.
Important note:
I haven't completed the whole game yet because it's so fun and I don't want to complete it so fast :).

Introduction:
Dying Light is an open world zombie survival horror FPS game with great parkour elements. Game is like a mix of Mirror's Edge parkour style with Dead Island slashing zombies gameplay style. Game feautures 4 player Co-op and you can complete whole campaign with your buddies or random players. There is also 4vs1 Be the zombie mode which lets play as the night hunter :).
Story:
I don't want to spoil anything, so I will tell you only first minutes of the game but just in case SPOILER ALERT!!!






You are Kyle Crane, GRE agent with special classified mission which you will see on yourself ;). You are dropped to Harran city but the situation got little complicated. I won't tell you the rest because story is interesting and you need to see it on yourself ;).

I don't want to get you bored so quickly so I will go straight to Pros and Cons :).
Pros:
+ Amazing and satisfying gameplay that gives a lot of fun.
+ Parkour is AWESOME and it's better than in Mirror's Edge :D.
+ Interesting story( at least for me :) ).
+ Very good optimization.
+ Nice graphics and sound effects.
+ Good soundtrack.
+ Co-op and Be the zombie mode.
+ Atmosphere.
+ Good voice acting.
+ Lots of secrets and Easter Eggs.
+ Many little side stories.
+ Main and side quests.
+ Day and night cycle which completely changes the gameplay.
+ Weapons wear out.
+ EXP system and character skill tree.
and more :D

Cons:
- Lip sync is  sometimes weird :D.
I can't remember more. Maybe some little bugs that are hard to find ;).

Finally I wanted to say to all that have doubts about Dying Light . BUY this game, it's so EPIC, you won't regret this decision :).
Thank you for getting to this point of my review :).
P.S. If you don't need cards from Dying Light I will be honored to take care of them :).

reviewText:
A joyously fun game with a lot of glaring issues holding it back from true greatness.

It brings to the table an exceptionally enjoyable combat system which feels like what Dead Island's combat should have been in the first place, while adding the wonderous addition of parkour elements to the combat and in turn making everything feel much more dynamic, though combat slowly becomes easier over time against normal zombies, but it gets balanced out by ne, stronger special infected. The infected slowly get introduced throughout the story and become part of the open world thereafter. Though combat can become repetitive and frustrating at times, with some enemies taking more hits than they really should.

The storyline is very predictable and fairly poorly written, though at the same time oddly charming and engaging in a Resident Evil kinda way. Where while the story is ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•, you still wanna see it through just to find out what horrible line or event will be demonstrated next. Not much else to say here.

Quests are decently varied though sometimes a bit repetitive in nature. There are a lot of basic fetch quests, but there's also quite a few scripted story based quests with an interesting layout and areas exclusive to the mission. Side quests feel like other story quests instead of basic small side things. They can become fairly engaging and enjoyable, though yet again may become repetitive.

The parkour system is implemnted quite flawlessly and is one of the best elements of the game, it feels silky smooth gliding from building to building, or from zombie to a roof of a far. Some of the most enjoyable parkour elements I've experienced within a game to date.

My absolute favorite element of the game is the nighttime though. It turns it into one of the most threatening and intereting experiences within open world games, an experience usually only seen within scripted linear experiences.
There's nothing more exhillerating than quietly sneaking past the large infected to get to an air drop, before being seen and having to run like all hell to a safe house from a horde before being taken down and killed. Absolutely wonderous.

Visually the game is absolutely gorgeous. Wonderful lighting, wonderful shading, wonderful models, wonderful animations. Sometimes shoddy texture work does not detract from the beautiful world Techland has crafted.

Performance wise the game runs alright currently. Though pre-patch it ran like complete ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• on hardware that should be able to run it perfectly fine. THough even post-patch it still has issues utilising all CPU cores and using SLI properly.
There's also the fact that AMD/ATI users are basically ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ed by Techland's optimisation for their hardware.  WHich is a major issue.

The game sadly lacks its own charm and personality. Instead feeling like another new AAA game. There's nothing truly memorable about it. Dead Island had some ridiculous memorable stuff such as Sam B, the wonderous jumping animation and the silly yet unique style. This game has Crane unsure of what to do before proceeding to be silent during actual gameplay. While Dead Island had the characters doing their own ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• yet hilarious one-liners, screams and moans.
It just feels oddly generic.

Overall it's a game full of ideas, some which it fulfills and some which it stumbles with. It takes a lot of elements from a lot of games, and does some well and some poorly. There's a lot of technical issues and the game can become fairly repetitive.

Though ultimately, what is here is a very entertaining and ambitous, though not memorable, game from Techland.

I give it a 7.5/10

reviewText:
Dying Light: Basically Dead Island gone right as many of these reviews probably already say. I played through the whole game with a friend and I can say there wasn't a moment where I was getting bored of it, My friend and I mostly trying to avoid the main quests and mostly just screwing around/doing side quests had a blast and thought it was very unfortunate when there wren't a many side quests to do in the Old Town part, but the recent addition of Hard mode made it 10x more challenging and 10x more fun. We honestly could say we were getting bored of the game when we were able to one hit Goons, but with hard mode that was instantly fixed, even the normal zombies were made a challenge.

The story focuses on Kyle Crane who is an agent sent in by the GRE to get files back from survivors who supposedly stole them, but to Crane's findings they actually were not the ones who stole them and so in turn he started helping them out, and thats pretty much how the introduction to the game starts. The story itself has a couple cliche moments but not enough to make the story predictable. There are a good amount of plot twists and parts that are honestly very sad when you realise what is happening.

Overall I would rate it:
8/10 Singleplayer
10/10 Multiplayer
Seriously, the addition of Co-op was probably the best thing this game has.

My friend personally gives it:
7/10 Singleplayer
10/10 Multiplayer

We have gotten a full enjoyment of the game and I can say that all these hours I've spent in this game are well worth it.
Thanks for reading.

reviewText:
I got this gift as a gift on May 22. So far, as of typing this out, I have enjoyed myself well beyond what one could. The atmosphere is enjoyable. The game presents a challenge that most games do not provide. The storyline has been nothing short of immersive.

The game is essentially if Dead Rising and Borderlands had a child and somehow Mirror's Edge was romantically involved.

My ratings so far?

Graphics: 8.5/10
Reason for rating: There are a few graphical glitches that could be easily remedied with a bit of investigative coding and some of the options are much too overpowering that could be toned down a pinch or be given an option for a lower setting. But for this, the natural bloom and shading makes the game much more menacing when playing, especially during the night in-game, which is -exactly- what I'd expect from something with a dramatic, eerie toned game like this.

Storyline: 7/10
Reason for rating: To start, the negatives are far outweighed by the positives. The storyline was engaging, however short it was, though my gripes with certain parts could be very notable, further dragging down my potential rating for this section. Subtlety felt lacking in certain parts of the game, especially during the end. Though the aspect was expected, perhaps different approaches could have been made to meet the main points in the story. With that being said, the storyline kept me hooked until one of the end missions.

Gameplay: 8.75/10
Reason for rating: So far, the enjoyment out of searching for secrets, better gear, and beyond, is what makes the game for me. I absolutely adore open worlds and a good questing system, as it allows for the ability to immerse yourself further by forcing you to explore and see the city of Harran as it is now and get ideas of what it was prior. The crafting system feels familiar yet different in how it's approached. My only bother with crafting like this is that I cannot set macros or access some form of GUI to craft on the fly naturally.


My major gripe about this game isn't about the single player aspect, but the multiplayer. When poking and prodding at the Be The Zombie" game mode

reviewText:
This game is not just your casual zombie or surivival game, this is the real stuff. There is no possibility to choose between easy/medium/hard mode. Might wanna get a friend to play with, sometimes its real boring when you are alone. Get a friend and play co-op together. Endless fun.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

PROS

+ Astonishing graphics and sun
+ AMAZING and unique parkour mechanics
+ Crazy and real look alike cinematics
+ Beautiful huge urban area to explore
+ Able to spend skill points on useful abilities.
+ Awesome night time gameplay, real challenging.
+ Huge range of weapons
+ Crafting system (weapons included)
+ Zombies have a different look compared to other Zombie games, makes it original.
+ Hundreds of sub-missions
+ Active developers team to fix bugs, optimization problems, addition of new graphics, etc.
+ Well made story
+ Perfect soundtrack that applies to parkour and zombie killing situations.
+ Ability to enter almost every house in order to scavenge
+ Picklock system
+ Co-op with 4 players
+ Multiplayer, with the ability to play as the night hunter


CONS

- Horrible optimization. I couldnt play if it wasnt for that Nvidia driver for Dying Light. But I'm still struggling due to my AMD processor. (Although they are working on fixing it, lets see what they make out of it)
- Weapons break faster than they are supposed to. There are even some weapons that can't actually even break in real life.
- No suppressors to craft/use on guns.
- Stealth is really, but REALLY poor in this game. When you sneak up behind someone you can't snap his neck or even kill him with 1 slash in the head. They are supposed to die right on the impact because they are not aware of it.
- Low presence and finding rate of firearms in the game. You simply can't make a zombie game without firearms. Guns are rare in the game and they said that snipers would be available. I couldn't find a single sniper throughout the whole game. Its more a hack and slash game. It gets pretty repetetive slashing zombies all day. I already heard rumors about a DLC weapon pack, if its true I just have one thing to say. Please, no.
- Theres no primitive way to survive, like making bows by using a hatch to get wood from trees. Its all about scavenging.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
I recommend this game, but it still needs a lot of improvement. This game has a lot to prove due to its active developement team that works on the complaints of players and future additions to the game.

reviewText:
Final Review:
As I stated in my previous update, this game has some issues with AI and NPC voice acting but these are just little issues in what is an excellent game. Considering this is Techlands first big project, the little issues that do exist are excusable. I'm very much looking forward to their future projects.

My overall marks are:
Graphics - 9/10
Gameplay - 9/10 (would have been 10 if it wasn't for AI issues)
Story - 8/10

Overall, this is a great game that has enjoable combat mechanics and a decent story. My one other issue is under spoiler alert, which is to do with the end game.

****Spoiler Alert****
Somewhat disappointed that the final fight amounted to hitting certain buttons when told to in an interactive cut scene. It would not have been hard to design the final fight to be a full on melee battle or gun fight. However, the lead up to that fight was intense and exciting.


Update 28/1/15:
Still no patch but have managed to get the game to run with an acceptable 30 to 45 fps while out in the open world. Did this by dropping the view distance down to nothing and turning off HBAO. Enjoying the game now, just wish I didn't have to compromise on the graphics.

In terms of the game, it is pretty good. I have some gripe with the AI of human NPC's, when going for an air drop I just throw molotovs at them; the NPC's that don't get hit by the molotov just stand there and watch their buddies burn to death. Also, some of the zombie AI is iffy, I have seen human NPCs stand next to zombies, side by side, neither of them attacking the other. The only other negative is that most of the male characters look the same and some of the voices do not fit the faces, so much so that it is comical on occasions.

But the game is enjoyable, killing zombies feels good although human AI is predictable. The parkour element is well put together. It may seem that I have more negative to say about the game than I do positive but at the time of writing this I have only played for a few hours. The purpose of this update to my review is to give some feedback on the game itself as my original review was about its poor optimisation.

At this stage, even with all its flaws I do recommend this game. I will extend my review at a later date.

Beware AMD GPU users, the game may not run very well with your GPU, even if you have a high quality one like I do.



Original Review:
Right now the game is unplayable as when I am outside my FPS drops below 25. Running with an AMD FX8350 and Radeon R9 270x. Seems to me from looking at the rest of the reviews, this game has been poorly optimized for AMD systems, regardless of what all the Nvidia fanboys are saying.


All those having the same issue, go to this link:
http://en.support.techland.pl/support/solutions/articles/4000042573-creating-dxdiag-file

Send them a dxdiag file to help them fix these problems more quickly.

reviewText:
Zombie FarCry . . . which is a good thing! 8.5/10, read on for more detail.

This game plays in an incredibly similar way to FC3 (and FC4 I'm assuming, although I've yet to play). The graphics are of a similar nature, the handling is similar, the crafting and skills aquisition is similar, the open world environment is similar, the quest system is similar, etc. It really feels familiar if you've played FarCry.

That being said, it's obviously got unique elements, such as the parkour movement around the city and the general atmosphere.

A+ on graphics (which I run fully maxed out on my i7 4770k, GTX 770 4gb, 16gb rig). Controls are easy enough once you practice. Parkour elements pretty smoothly integrated and intuitive. Combat thus far feels pretty smooth and realistic, although precision hitting with a pipe is proving difficult. Sound is absolutely top notch (hearing things all around me, things sound hellish at night, very immersive).

Gameplay is tense and you definitely are presented with a nice balance of feeling like a badass, but also terrified out of your wits at times. Only complaint is sheer amount of cutscenes and times when you sit back and watch, rather than play. I'm OK with these, as I think they add cinematic drama to most games, but it does feel a bit over the top here.

No technical issues, install was a breeze, no crashes or bugs yet. So nice to play a AAA title after so many early access games in the last year or two.

Overall, great game that I'm looking forward to playing through, then again in co-op.

reviewText: Definitely a worthy purchase. So far I have barely played into 15% of the story as the sidequests have be going without it feeling like a chore. Day/Night cycle works very subtly and works well. Personally, night does scare me. Even knowing the Volatiles position as they're marked on your minimap you will constantly check your back and when you get chased it becomes very tense. I find the night to be quite balanced, as the volatiles run faster than you but climb slower so you have to take advantage of the mirrors-edge style parkour that the game perfectly placed in, making it a much more interesting version of Dead Island with the free roaming aspect of it - quite unique to input a parkour system into a zombie game, but it was definitely a good mashup. I myself am not even a horror fan and I enjoy this game - it doesn't try to be scary, and usually isn't - fans of Action/RPG games will definitely enjoy this, even if you found Dead Island to be dull.

reviewText:
Dead Cool

Whether their Romero ‚Äúshamblers‚Äù or Dawn of the Dead (2004) ‚Äúsprinters‚Äù, there‚Äôs just something cool about zombies which elevates them above all other B-Movie monsters.

They‚Äôre human, they used to be us and that thought is as scary as hell.
An Outbreak starts with just one infected but their numbers continue to grow as ours diminish, if we get bitten, we‚Äôll turn ourselves.
It‚Äôs such a perfect apocalyptic scenario and one which is happily experiencing a renaissance at the moment.


The Rise of the Zombies

From reality TV shows to block buster movies, Video games to survival manuals, zombie pop culture is everywhere these days and I love it.

I‚Äôve seen all the movies, I‚Äôve watched all the TV shows, I‚Äôve played most of the games, I‚Äôm a consumer of all things zombie (although, should the opportunity arise, don‚Äôt actually consume a zombie, it‚Äôll only end badly for you.)


Morning has Broken

I‚Äôve also put a lot of thought into what actions I would take should I open my curtains one morning to find the zombie apocalypse taking place on my front lawn.

Amongst all my plans of stockpiling Pot Noodles and keeping a bucket in the attic to poo in, I‚Äôve never considered that being skilled in the art of parkour might be a useful survival trait; at least I hadn‚Äôt considered it until very recently when I stumbled upon my latest piece of zombie content to consume.


Apocalypse All Over Again

You remember the first Dead Island game? It was pretty good right? Well the fine folks at Techland have released another tasty undead treat into the world, a stealthy, action, parkour, survival zombie treat in the form of Dying Light.


City of the Dead

In Dying Light the undead plague has emerged, but the powers that be have responded quickly and contained it to a small area, the fictional city of Harran.

Quarantined off from the rest of the world and relying on vital air drops courtesy of the Global Relief Effort, the situation inside the city continues to deteriorate, and if HBO‚Äôs The Walking Dead has taught us anything, it‚Äôs that you don‚Äôt just need to worry about the undead, other groups of survivors can be for more deadly.

This rings true in Dying Light as a gang mentality has gripped the crumbling city of Harran where two prominent groups are vying for supplies whilst struggling to survive the undead, but all is not lost...


Keep Taking the Pills

Whilst there isn‚Äôt a cure, there is a medicine (Antizen) that the infected can take which delays the turning, as long as they keep taking Antizen they‚Äôll be ok, however the only source of this medication comes from the supply planes flying relief missions over the city.


Going Down

The game opens with your character preparing to parachute into Harran whilst receiving instructions from his employer over a radio; it seems that there is a survivor in the city that holds some very sensitive information, information which cannot be made public and it‚Äôs your job to retrieve it.

You‚Äôll then find yourself falling through the sky towards the infested city, but things don‚Äôt start off well at all!

A hard landing and an encounter with the locals (both the alive and dead varieties) later and you‚Äôll be bitten, infected and dragged to the first safe zone of the game. This is where you man hunt truly begins.


Running Man

From this point you‚Äôll be meeting new characters and trying to earn their trust by running missions for them, and I literally mean running, the big thing that sets Dying Light apart from the Dead Island titles is the ‚ÄúFree Running‚Äù game mechanic.

You‚Äôll be tearing across roof tops, leaping alleyways and scaling the sides of buildings.

The safest way to stay alive in Harran is to stay off the ground; a casual walk down the street will see you surrounded and overwhelmed by zombies quicker than you can say ‚ÄúAssassins Creed of the Dead‚Äù.


Long Jump

In the increasingly crowded zombie gaming genre this parkour style of play is hugely refreshing and better still it is exceptionally well implemented.

With a gamepad in hand, you‚Äôll find the controls are really dialled in, look where you want to go, hit the jump button and there‚Äôs a good chance you‚Äôll make it, it‚Äôs not only intuitive, it makes you feel like a free running bad ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•!


Do me a Favour?

The missions themselves are the usual mix of ‚Äúgo there‚Äù, ‚Äúkill that‚Äù and ‚Äúfetch this‚Äù quests that we know and love, completion of which will give you the experience you‚Äôll need to level up your various abilities enabling you to hit a little harder and jump a little further, you might even learn some new skills along the way.


Be Crafty

Dying Light also boasts a pretty deep crafting system. You‚Äôll be rummaging through bins and patting down corpses like a perverted Womble looking for the things that every day folk leave behind.
There are plenty of crafting recipes to learn, from Med Kits to Molotov‚Äôs there‚Äôs a plethora of useful items and weapons just waiting for your crafty hands to bring them into existence.
I can‚Äôt overstate how useful a well placed Molotov is when you‚Äôre in a tight spot.


Zombie Farm

All zombies are not born equal in Dying Light, the recently infected will move a hell of lot quicker than the common stale variety of zombie you‚Äôll see shambling around.
You‚Äôll discover zombies that spit, zombies that explode, radioactive zombies in hazmat suits, and plenty of others, Hazmat is a dangerous place to explore at any time of day.


The Dead of Night

But at night, that‚Äôs when things really become scary. The whole atmosphere of the game changes when night falls, it‚Äôs much tenser and you really want to stay out of site, stealthily moving from one secluded spot to another. You really don‚Äôt want to attract any attention at night.

There are super fast zombies lurking in the darkness and you‚Äôre going to have trouble outrunning them. The pitch dark makes your parkour aerobatics much more difficult to pull off as you rush through the streets, the feeble pool of light from your torch dancing along the landscape in front of you.


Sleep It Off

Being outside at night is a serious business, but you do have the option to sleep through the night in a safe zone if it all becomes a little too much, although some missions will require you to go out at night, there‚Äôs no avoiding it completely


Dead Pretty

In addition to the daytime being slightly less stressful, being out in the sunlight gives you a chance to drink in the scenery, the city of Harran can be a visually stunning place to explore.

From the sun bleached rooftops to the ominous darkness of the underpasses, everything about Harran exudes atmosphere, the whole city feels alive, which is no easy feat for a city full of the dead!


Dead End

If the Dead Island games were the warm up act then Dying Light is the main event.
With  glossy visuals, satisfying combat mechanics and an outstanding parkour system, Dying Light is a fantastic game and the city of Harran is a beautifully realised setting begging to be explored.

You should take the time to visit, just don't go for the night life, it's dead.



For the full review and others please take the time to visit http://www.review-well.com

When it aims for high drama, it comes off like a George Romero soap opera: think Days of the Dead of Our Lives. When it gets on with the less serious business of running, climbing and kicking zombies in their bottoms, it‚Äôs marvellous fun.

reviewText:
This was one of (very few) games that got me psyched about 2015. The concept was excellent, and a lot of the time, the game delivered.

Pros:
- Excellent visuals got me standing on a rooftop just looking towards the rising sun (just before jumping down and bolting because some ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• *** Viral is chasing me), although, I did have to run on medium textures as the mere 2GB frame buffer of my GTX 960 (don't even say it) had the game stuttering
- Free-running mechanic is, in my opinion, the best of any video game (beating AC and Mirror's Edge)
- Excellent combat system, making me think about how to best use the available stamina to either kill all of the zombies in my vicinity or run
- Wide range of weapons (plus some interesting modifications)
- Hilarious drop kick
- Brilliant Easter Eggs (my favourite was the Plants Vs. Zombies one)
- Interesting variation of zombies (demolishers were a particular pain in the ***)
- Excellent community had me make a couple of Steam friends
- Brilliant PvP gameplay, really gets you thinking about tactics to get the kills (especially on the zombie side)
- Good skill tree system allows well progressed development of in-game skills

Cons:
- Mediocre story with a disappointing QTE ending (although, in terms of plot, I don't think the ending was all bad, just enough to want me coming back for more)
- Disappointing characters with no real depth (I'm looking at you, Crane and Jade). I just didn't feel connected to the characters (although, I found myself a little moved at  Rahim's  death)
- Dumb ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• villain with a philosphy and physique ripped straight out of Far Cry 3
- ****ing torch
- Lack of content in terms of missions (approximately 45 in total)
- Little emphasis on stealth (especially with human combatants)
- Lack of character customisation, possible inclusion of character creation (although, with developer tools being released, at least outfits should be fair game)

I would have liked to see more focus on specialisation rather than maxing out all skill trees, would have allowed for a greater variety of gameplay styles (I'm more in the mindset to avoid zombies and hit hard and fast on reduced numbers when I have to).

I love this game, and I will continue playing it in coop and PvP. I sincerely hope they release a DLC continuing with the story (or branching off and creating a new one). I don't agree with the hate on this game's ending.  Going to Dr. Camden and curing the virus would have been way more anti-climatic than the current one.

Props to Techland for the excellent game (and leaving the ****heads at Deep Silver for the disappointment that was Dead Island).

reviewText:
Attention to detail. I am a sucker for detail, and this game really has it, you can really feel how much polishing and effort went into this game, the physics based combat provides plenty of fun ways to kill zombies, mostly consisting of kicking and drop kicking, the character movement feels smooth and is genuinely fun. The skills and leveling feel very rewarding, running around at night is scary but it's made worth it in XP gains. This game is a 10/10 when it comes to gameplay, not many games provide the level of satisfaction that this game does.

Performance is this games weakest point and what initially kept me from buying this game. On a R9 270x my fps gets pretty bad fluctuations, the good thing is that it's only in the beggining where it's unbearable, after you get away from the towers then gameplay becomes smooth.

The story, quests, and dialog feels 'realistic' and interesting although being a little predictable. My only real complaint is that I recieved a quest to collect 3 100lb bus batteries, the giver made specials notes about it being heavy and requiring ape like strength, but when collecting the batteries they went into my inventory just like any other item. Most people would have a difficult time scaling walls and fences with 300 pounds of batteries shoved up their ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•.

reviewText:
Don't go into the game expecting a Zombie Murder Simulator (like Dead Island). Dying Light is a survival game at heart with a bit of optional stealth. You'll spend time scavenging for materials and equipment and the game generally rewards exploration. You'll never be quite so happy to find string and bits of metal as you will be when playing Dying Light.

The parkour elements are pretty damned good, although there are a few jumps that are hard to guage. Overall, it's basically like Mirror's Edge in this regard, without the visual queues though.

No weapon is permanent, everything will break down or run out of ammo. This forces you to keep scavenging for new stuff, to keep upgrading your equipment.

Also, there's still an ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• designer who likes to put exploding zombies behind doors.

reviewText:
One playthrough, just finished.

OK, this is a solid First-Person Errand Boy Simulator. With a zombie theme.
The general gameplay is of a well-known type: Run across town, get things done, don't get killed and don't kill yourself by accident. The story is pretty good, especially so for the zombie-themed game, the atmosphere, especially in the beginning, is fantastic - later you'll become a sort of Conan the Barbarian in the Zombieland, so the appeal of the grim and agressive zombie-infested environment will move from appealing to tedious. As usual, I'd say. Still, quite enjoyable, solidly build and exciting game.

Good things:
+Mostly nice and compelling story with a good pace. The protagonist, Crane, is, simply put, a nice guy to have around when you play. He is quite vocal, to the point that his attitude sometimes happen to mirror the player's emotions - oh, the frustration of moving through the zombie hordes to get one stupid keycard... it almost brings down the forth wall, in a good way. Also, he is not entirely stupid, which is a grace - you won't feel that Oh snap

reviewText:
Let me just say that I'm also tired of zombie games. But I'm also tired of zombie games that are made by poor and bad developers. Dying Light however, is a good game. Though made by the creators of Dead Island which might turn off most of you guys.

If you're worried that this game will be not worth your time because it's made by the same creators of Dead Island, drop your worries right now. This is a good game for real this time. To be honest, I also like Dead Island a bit despite it's unfinished quality.

Now before I continue, let me put a spoiler warning because, I'm going to be explaining the story right now. Skip this if you don't want the story spoiled.

**SPOILER ALERT**

You play as Kyle Crane. Working for the GRE which, I think is a secret government agency. Your mission being you have to receive private information from your target and kill him. As you arrive in town, things go to hell and you get infected. After looking for a shipment containing crates of antizen which surpresses the symptoms of the infection, GRE contacts you saying that you have to burn some the crates. Kyle didn't want to, but was forced to. Hours of doing favours for the survivors that saved him, he's now in a constant battle between the trust of the survivors that saved him and his boss on the radio.

*END*

Let's talk about the gameplay now. To be expected, it plays a lot like Dead Island with new features. There's the epic parkour system. If you've played Assassin's Creed before, it's kind of like that except in 1st person. The game starts out a little slow as you're really vulnerable to the zombies when you first start out. Especially when it turns dark and super zombies start patrolling the streets.

If one super zombie spots you while you're out at night, you better get out of there right now. There's no sense in running since they run faster than you. They can also parkour like you can. Fortunately, there are ways of dealing with them to prevent them from chasing you.

As you survive, you get different experience points depending on what you've been doing. If you run, jump and climb a lot, you'll get Agility XP. This allows you to perform better tricks at getting around the environment. If you hit and kill zombies, you'll get Combat XP. Which allows you to perform better and deadlier attacks. Yes you do get Combat XP just by hitting them so, there's no need to finish the zombie off. Though you get extra Combat XP for doing so.

Finally, there's Survival XP. This is achieved through helping out your survivors. Which include completing quests, bringing them supplies from airdrops or helping other survivors that are in trouble. You'll also get Survival XP based on how long you survived through the night without dying. Oh and there's one good reason about being out at night. If you can stay out of the way of the super zombies, the XP you gain will be doubled for Agility and Combat. Like if you get 15 Agility XP for climbing over a fence at day, you'll get 30 instead if you do it at night. But remember, night is very difficult.

Now the combat is just like Dead Island. Smack at the zombies face until it stops moving or its head explodes in to a gooey red paste. Though don't swing too much or else you'll tire out. Now here's another good thing. There's regular stamina and combat stamina. Regular stamina is only used when you sprint and run around while combat stamina is only used whenever you swing your weapon. This is good because, there will be times where you'll have to dodge out of the way whenever you run out of combat stamina. No dodging doesn't use combat stamina thankfully. Also like Dead Island, you can add elemental upgrades to your weapons and as well as modifications that add bonus stats to your weapons. Though weapons only have a few slots of modding and weapons will degrade until they break if used too much. Not to mention they only have a few number of repairs before repairing does absolutely nothing. Once you used all the repair slots on the weapon, it's time to get a replacement. Not everything lasts forever and this is especially true to items in real life.

The graphics is amazing. The sun glares beautifully at your face and the destroyed and dark urban scenery really makes you feel sad for it. The sound is great too and it can even make you scared and really make you get goosebumps. Which I think is cool because, it adds a good horror element to it. The characters of the game also make you want to care for them. They have a good purpose for staying alive and even the main villain on the game makes you wish the guy was dead. He does a fantastic job at being a villain.

The co-op is also good. Running around the environment, completing quests and killing zombies together is really fun indeed. Also, there's a new mode called Be the Zombie" mode. This allows players to play a super zombie that also gets stronger just like when you play the campaign. These player controlled zombies are tough if you're very sneaky. You have to be a predator. Stalking your prey and waiting for the exact moment to strike. Not to mention this allows players to invade other player's games. It's just like in Dark Souls whenever you get invaded by a red spirit. Though you do have the choice of turning off invasion like a pansy if you want.

Also the special zombies from Dead Island are also back. The slow walking biters
recommended: the big zombie that wields a big stone rebar
hoursPlayed: the acid spitting spitter and the exploding bomber. These add more to the difficulty and tension to the game as you need to be careful when facing these special infected.\n\nNow you guys might be wondering what are the bad things to this game? You make it sound like it's one of the best games ever. Well
