reviewText: dying light was a fantastic game from start to finish. while i feel the story itself wasn't that long in either the main game or the following dlc, there was plenty of side missions and activities to keep me interested/distracted. 81 hours in and even though i've beaten the story, most of the side missions, and the following dlc (i don't have the bozak horde or ultimate survival bundle) i still find myself coming back to dying light for a number of reasons. the parkour system is the best i've ever seen. while the grappling hook detracts from the realsim of running around a city or across a countryside, it's quite an enjoyable addition and invaluable when it comes to quickly crossing the city of harran or getting back to your car to chase down the latest medical drop (SO happy they brought that back for the dlc) or rush off to help some random survivor from zombies or Rais's thugs. scattered around the city and countryside are plenty of challenges or races to keep you coming back. i wish there was a way to go from the city to the countryside without quitting to the main menu and starting up the dlc, but it's not much of an issue. i cannot stress enough how much fun it is to hop in your buggy and plow through a field of zombies and pop out the other side of the field to see yet another field of zombies to plow through. they really stepped up the carnage in the following dlc. i love it. and they don't make the car overpowered, either. if you smash into too much stuff and break different parts, the performance of the buggy noticably starts to suffer. ruined tires make you spin out, a busted accelerator means you're not gonna reach top speed fast enough. run out of gas and you're screwed until you find more. by the end of the main game, i wasn't that scared of volatiles or the night time anymore-the following changed all that. volatiles not only feel more dangerous, they're more numerous. and fast. so freaking fast. oh yeah! and the bolter liver repeatable side quest. hunting down bolters in your buggy to run them over and snatch their livers. all in all, if you like zombie games or parkour games or open world games, dying light is not a game you would wanna pass up

reviewText:
ENGLISH:

This game is a selective one. If you liked Dead Island you will probably liked this one too. Because it gives you;

-Parkour system which also means more freedom while rushing around.
-Basic level customization of weapons that you will find it easy to understand and apply.
-Day and Night cycle that gives you the true meaning of zombie rush.

Graphics are ok. Because when you are on the high settings there isn't really anything to bother you. Since gameplay is so smooth that sometimes you ignore the graphics. Also after updates game's stability boosted , I only countered 1 or 2 crash to desktop with my over 70 hours. I gotta say that I enjoyed both Dead Island and Dying Light.

If I had to write bad side of the game that would be ;

-Totally cliche characters that we don't even embrace.
-Short storyline
-Ending feels empty.
-Some minor glitches/bugs while freerunning on the narrow passes.

Hard mode and dead is dead" simply makes the game more fun but you lack of vision makes you little bit upset. So I advice you to complete the game on "normal" then go for a real fun at "hard" with "dead is dead" mentality.

There is a huge upcoming DLC and I believe it will add much more fun to game.

reviewText:
Wow.
The reviewers were very, very wrong.
So, i'll just go through a few things first.
1. The story is not ABSOLUTE GARBAGE. Sure it's generic, but some characters scan be likable, it's logical(to an extent) and it fills its position well.
2. It doesn't get boring. The brilliant mechanics here make it a joy to play. Don't take my word for it, look at the people with 30+ hours barely after release.
3. I love the human combat. If you use(abuse) the dodge mechanic, it makes the melee fights interesting versus the skull crunching of zombies.

Anyway, a few thoughts of mine on the game were that albeit the map looking awfully small, the verticality, claustrophobia, terrifying night mode, and imminent danger while on the ground leaves it constantly new, as you're moving too frantically to really pay much attention.

The parkour is absolutely fantastic, with a well worked out skill tree that has very fair progression. It's fluid, fun, and quick, compensating for the hordes of versatile undead.

Speaking of the zombies, I love them. Unlike most gorefest games, these zombies are rarely easy to kill. They're resilient and persistent, making sure that you always second guess that escape plan.

Nighttime is absolutely brilliant, the startling shift of atmosphere and gameplay is jarring and great. The volatiles are terrifying, and I have never enjoyed such a chase as the ones in this game. With the freerunning here the pursuits are pulse pounding and fun. Never have I loved the eerie violet glow of UV lighting more.

Multiplayer is fun, the night hunter is terrifying. The invasion idea is great. Playing as the zombie is fantastic as well.

Weapons are good, I hate the speed at which they break, but it adds a sense of conservation and urgency that's important. Upgrades are interesting, guns are rare enough and dangerous enough to nearly be useless, and the melee produce such a satisfying *crunch* that I rarely use guns anyway.

Soundwork is great when it isnt the voicing. Lots of groans, pops, crunches, etc make it feel real.

Harran is a great setting for this. Really.

KICKING


Overall, the story's failings are made up for in excess by incredibly addictive gameplay. I may not have played much yet, but I have had more fun than in any game from last year in it's entirety.

EDIT: Quick tip: there ARE bugs. Right now i'm stuck where I need to open an elevator, but the doors stay shut without allowing me the command. Watch out for bugfixing updates and wait it out for that if that's your thing.

reviewText:
TL;DR - This game in my opinion is easily the #1 in its genre and there is very little reason to skip it. Offers fun gameplay and combat with good variety.

If you want an open-world zombie ''survival'' game, this one is the best in the market. Hell, even if you just want a game that contains zombies, this is the best one you'll find.

Now, i put ''survival'' in quotations (or whatever its called) because you collect things around the world to craft bombs, weapons, med kits and all that. It's not entirely survival and if anyone claims so, i would disagree. It is sort of post-apocalyptic which makes it look survival, but there is no nutritional crisis, where you'd have to go look for food before you starve, so in my opinion its not a survival game.

The game is well-ported in my opinion, i have a pretty bad PC and can run it quite fine, and the graphics are quite pleasant too (you need to know what settings to tune down though).

What can be annoying for some here is that all weapons are degradable and will be destroyed to uselessness as you use them. You can repair them, but only for a fixed amount of times. What's good with this system however, is that it keeps your weapon variety going and keeps the game interesting in combat to a slight degree (This becomes less of a struggle as the game goes when you can obtain really good stuff too easily).

The zombies are really braindead, but you have some empowered ones that can be pretty tough at times. At night time, you'll have some extremely hard monsters to deal with and its almost never recommended to be out at night unless you want a huge adrenaline rush because it can be insanely hard, sometimes scary. In a nutshell they're really fun to fight.

Story has some plot to it but i assume its nothing special, since people never take stories in open world games seriously as far as i know, but i enjoyed the story. It was nice to follow it along, and it made you feel pretty important, though you're more like just a running slave.

The side-activities arent as interesting but if you want to punch more zombies, they're quite nice. Some involve parkour and gathering aswell.

This game supports lots of mods, and there is even custom games where people create their own maps. As soon as we get more content in on this, this could be tons of fun with others or just alone. I'd say this the core ''end'' game you'll be spending your time with after you complete the story, unless you wanna mess around some more over there.

reviewText: dying light was a fantastic game from start to finish. while i feel the story itself wasn't that long in either the main game or the following dlc, there was plenty of side missions and activities to keep me interested/distracted. 81 hours in and even though i've beaten the story, most of the side missions, and the following dlc (i don't have the bozak horde or ultimate survival bundle) i still find myself coming back to dying light for a number of reasons. the parkour system is the best i've ever seen. while the grappling hook detracts from the realsim of running around a city or across a countryside, it's quite an enjoyable addition and invaluable when it comes to quickly crossing the city of harran or getting back to your car to chase down the latest medical drop (SO happy they brought that back for the dlc) or rush off to help some random survivor from zombies or Rais's thugs. scattered around the city and countryside are plenty of challenges or races to keep you coming back. i wish there was a way to go from the city to the countryside without quitting to the main menu and starting up the dlc, but it's not much of an issue. i cannot stress enough how much fun it is to hop in your buggy and plow through a field of zombies and pop out the other side of the field to see yet another field of zombies to plow through. they really stepped up the carnage in the following dlc. i love it. and they don't make the car overpowered, either. if you smash into too much stuff and break different parts, the performance of the buggy noticably starts to suffer. ruined tires make you spin out, a busted accelerator means you're not gonna reach top speed fast enough. run out of gas and you're screwed until you find more. by the end of the main game, i wasn't that scared of volatiles or the night time anymore-the following changed all that. volatiles not only feel more dangerous, they're more numerous. and fast. so freaking fast. oh yeah! and the bolter liver repeatable side quest. hunting down bolters in your buggy to run them over and snatch their livers. all in all, if you like zombie games or parkour games or open world games, dying light is not a game you would wanna pass up

reviewText:
System:  asus 970gtx , 8gb ram, i5 3570k @4ghz

This game is excellent - Honestly , it is.
I must admit that when I first played it I pirated it, but then, when the Following came out I actually bought the game as it was THAT GOOD.
Movement in this game is like in no other game I have EVER played - it is seamless, fluent and fast.

Fighting is just perfect - it gives lots of satisfaction and a lot of fun . It has never been so fun to chop zombies heads off.
You can shoot them with a bow with exploding arrow, you can drop kick them on the wall full of spikes. It is FUN!!!

Driving a buggy is well thought out and brings a lot of joy after a day of hard work in real life.

Crafting menu could be slightly better (you will end up with a long list of items) but it is not a big issue. You can make all sorts of weapons, upgrade them , salvage them, trade etc. I LOVE that.

Looting - I LOVE IT.

Exploring - I LOVE IT ! Some days I basically run through the game and explore houses etc

Graphics - you WILL NOT find a game with better graphics - honestly. I played it all (Mad Max, FC4, MGS 5 etc.)

This game is like a perfect mixture of parkour, fighting, looting and exploring.

CO-OP is excellent , the game feels fresh when you play with someone else and there are some hilarious moments when you play with friends

JUST BUY IT!!!

Melee system and Parkour mechanics works perfectly. Animations are nice and smooth. One of the few games today that justify its price point. Totally satisfied with the game and thats more than I can say for most games today. Great game.

reviewText:
Imagine if a developer took some concepts from Far Cry, Assassin's Creed and Mirror's Edge and kind of threw them on the top of the gameplay from Dead Island. Well, Techland has done just that, it's just that none of the concepts really work that well and all the issues from Dead Island are still prevalent.

You kill fast zombies, slow zombies, strong zombies and exploding zombies. You make molotovs, grenades, medkits from items you find in the game world. There's quicktime events and unlockable skills and you've seen them all of this stuff before in some form or another, in any game you've probably played in the last decade.

I can't think of a good reason to recommend this game to anyone. At release it is horribly optimized and runs like crap, I've seen all manner of glitches and been victim to countless, cheap deaths. Killing zombies is about as unoriginal as it comes these days and the only time this game is worth picking up is if you see it in a bargain bin and even then, that's a stretch.

Full video review:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Pq12LWVk0uA

The Following however, is a lot more enjoyable, with a driveable Buggy, a different environment to explore and some new weapons and enemy types to play around with. More of the same, if that's your kind of thing.

Full video review:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FnQwm6eH_1s

reviewText:
Dying Light at first glance will remind you of Dead Island, with its focus on melee combat and the destruction of countless hordes of zombies, but on top of the similarities, there are vast improvements with its fluid gameplay, endless content and striking new mechanics.

Dying Light follows the story of an undercover GRE [Global Relief Effort] agent named Kyle Crane who is dropped into the infested city of Harran, a fictional city hinted to be situated in Turkey. Crane enters the city by C-130 tactical jump and stumbles across a group of armed men, following this first short encounter a zombie horde attacks and you are quickly rescued by two other people. These two people are apart of a community situated in an apartment building nicknamed ‚ÄòThe Tower‚Äô by its residents. From there you have your primary objective of finding extremely sensitive data which a GRE rogue agent has stolen and your superiors need it obtained. Whilst you tackle the task at hand you also will be asked to help people in the city which play a role as side missions within the game, these add to the stories related to the many interesting characters and give you a better sense of the trials and tribulations of the surviving people of Harran.

The controls and movement throughout the game are phenomenal and could be compared to Mirror‚Äôs Edge, personally, I would say it is a lot more freeform and has an emphasis on freedom and exploration. After all, Techland hired David Belle as a consultant to work on the games Parkour design and motion capture. David Belle is a French film actor, choreographer and stunt coordinator and is considered the founder or the leading pioneer of the Parkour, coining it based on his training and the teachings from his father Raymond Belle. Movement feels fun and the absence of vehicles at the start of the game [later on that] is not something that Dead Island fans will miss as getting places on foot is endless fun.

Amongst the carnage of infected you will also have to battle against humans too and to help you with that you will have access to a plethora of weapons, upgrades, and tools that all can be modified. Blueprints can be found around the city to unlock the ability to craft custom weapons from items you pick up whilst on missions. There are three main skill trees to upgrade which add an RPG element to the game, survival, agility, and power. Survival assists in general abilities in relation to exploration. Agility provides for quicker movement and improved Parkour ability. Power relates to your engagement with enemies and the types of attacks against enemies that can help do insane amounts of damage. Gaining XP is pretty simple, for Agility all you have to do is move, climb, jump and travel distance. For Power XP all that is required is hit zombies, kill zombies in new ways or just shoot them down with a hail of bullets. To get survival points it is a little less constant, it‚Äôll require helping out recovering supply drops for the friendly survivors and completing certain tasks for them.

Time of day makes a huge difference in this game‚Äôs gameplay. Not only is night time near pitch black, but it‚Äôs so dangerous that EXP gained for Power and Agility are doubled. Being out at night time is a matter of risk vs reward as death is likely to happen. Nighttime is when special enemies called ‚ÄòVolatiles‚Äô appear. They are twice the size of a normal zombie, they are powerful, and faster than the player. The only way to survive them is to avoid them or use the verticality of the city to help escape them by shifting direction.

Multiplayer is present in the form of 4 player coop and separate modes including 4 players vs volatiles [be the zombie mode] and Deathmatch mode, which was introduced in later patches. There is an invasion system throughout the campaign, players can invade your single player game with a volatile hunter and it can really keep you on edge, of course, this is a toggleable feature.

Dying Light runs on the Chrome Engine 6, one version up from Dead Island‚Äôs Chrome Engine 5. The visual improvements are obvious as soon as you launch the game, even on a console. Improved 3D sound, x64 High dynamic range rendering, higher resolutions shadows and within the first year of its release the developers released the ChromEd tool to allow for map/script making.
Model Detail is one key visual feature that stands out over previous Techland titles, this is mainly obvious due to the enhanced zombie/creature detail ‚Äî but also can be seen in the environment, Harran has a very realistic mix between Northern Middle-East and Eastern European architecture.
Bozak Horde DLC

The Bozak Horde is a challenge/story DLC that adds a new weapon to the mix. The player wakes up in a small room and is told by the mysterious man called Bozak that a bomb has been attached to your leg and you are required to follow his dangerous and increasingly difficult requests. Through the DLC the player must attempt to complete 20 trials in the Harran stadium which will lead to the weapon unlock and some more story to add to the rich world of Harran.
The Following DLC
[MINOR SPOILERS]

After completing the main story campaign of Dying Light, Kyle Crane learns about a cultist group who seems to be naturally immune to the virus that effects Harran without the need for Antezin. They are living in the ‚ÄòCountryside‚Äô, the rural outskirts of the main city.  In order to gain information about the immunity and gaining the cult‚Äôs trust, he must assist the survivors living out in the ‚ÄòCountryside‚Äô. This DLC adds a wealth of content, including a minimum of 16 hours of story content, the ability to drive and upgrade a Dune buggy [also added to multiplayer], some new weapons including a Crossbow and a new map that is double the size of all other maps combined. The game at this stage gets a breath of fresh air with the addition of new characters and a new landscape to traverse. There is a new ranking system that also relates to Trust with the immune Cult group and also a later patch that unlocked much of the previous level cap, allowing for new upgrades and customization within the game.

In conclusion, you are looking at an extremely immersive game that will keep you entertained for hours, this is the game that Techland wanted to originally make during the Dead Island development and finally with the assistance of WB Games they could. The game will take around 28 hours to complete with the DLC content taking up to 18 hours to complete

Story 7
Sound 8
Gameplay 9
Visuals 9
Value 9

8.4 / 10

reviewText:
Dying Light is a zombie fighting survival game.

PRO:
-The Day/Night cycle is very well done and help build the atmosphere of the game as zombies scale to your level, so unless you join a friend who is just starting out, fighting is always a challenge no matter what time of the day.
-There's always a place to explore and scavenge, seriously like holy cow there's so much to find and look for I don't think you understand how much was put into the maps.
-Graphics aren't mindblowingly awesome but are gritty enough to really make you feel you are in a war-torn zombieland.
-The game doesn't shove crafting in your face. Like really all you need to craft early on is about 20 med packs, and you really don't need to do anything else. As a guy who really despises games who throw in crafting just to make it a selling point, it was reasuring to see that it wasn't a main focous of the development.
-Bashing heads dead or alive is so satisfying, really just seeing these litte buggers collapse to a well placed dome swing is just so rewarding in of itself.
-Mod suport!
-Night time is absolutely horrifying. During my time in the game I've never wanted to land once on the ground due to fear of what lurks below.

CON:
-Horrendously unoptimized. I've got a decent machine that can at least run these current gen types of games at high graphic levels, but all graphical features are either off or set on low.
-Freerunning isn't 100% ready, so you'll either be making jumps you didn't want or fall to your death multiple times.
-The game itself feels like it needed another month to squash out these bugs, though to their credit the dev team has been patching the game every 3 or so days, so at least they've been taking care of their baby (unlike most AAA games released these days).
-The main story really isn't something to sing praises, plot holes galore, uninteresting, tries to force emotion by taking lives of characters that aren't really estableshed, and the main villain acts like he's so deep and understands that humans are scum bla bla bla. All in all it takes maybe 4 hours if you power through missions like crazy.

TL;DR
7.5/10 if you like the number system. All in all just straight up fun zombie survival game that feels like it had lots of love put into it, something that you don't see in games of this caliber these days. Has bugs, but the developers have been patching this game to bring it to the high standards they've set themselves since release.

reviewText:
A lot of people doubted this game on forehand, including myself. But now that I've just finished the campaign, I can say no less than that this is the best Zombie-survival game I have ever played so far!
Not only is there a great combination of combat and parkour that mix up with each-other in a very awesome way, it also has a very good story that really dragged me in and almost made me demand myself to finish it.
The graphics look absolutely amazing and the movement is very smooth but still challenging at some times (so not always too easy).
Especially in the beginning parkour is not gonna be easy, but you earn skillpoints as you make progress to unlock better stamina, parkour skills, weapons and combat techniques and even a freaking grappling hook!

Parkour isn't just there because 'it's cool', but you're actually gonna need it to survive as the street are sometimes literally crowded up by zombie-hordes!
Lot's of very cool and modifiable weapons, from standard pipes and wrenches to machine rifles and fire-hatches.

Also, this is the first game that actually gave me a bit of 'the chills' at night.
It's not just like the lights go off and it's just a bit darker. No, it can get really flipping dark.. Sometimes you really aren't able to see a damn thing without your flashlight!
But that's just a small detail considering that at night, the zombies get more aggressive, start to hunt you down and lots of stronger, faster and smarter zombies get out of their holes.

All in all i'd say that if you're in to survival, zombies, a bit of horror, a good story and/or parkour, really don't hesitate to buy this game!

And the best part is; I may have finished the campaign the other day, but i'm still able to play co-op with my friends and just have some fun or do the actual campaign with them!

Only thing that could've made this game even better are a bow and arrow and maybe a bit less loot as it's really easy to find certain things.
And they maybe could've developed some characters a bit more in the story.

All in all, i'd say 9,2/10!

reviewText:
Like expected, it is similar to Dead Island in a lot of ways. So, where does it differ? Well, the graphics and general tone of the game are a lot grittier and darker than Dead Island. Think of this as the Empire Strikes Back to Dead Island's Star Wars.

The looting and melee part of the game is very similar. You pick up, trade, craft weapons and use blueprints to upgrade them and so on. They increase in damage as you level up and unlock rarer varieties.

The free-running is unique here - I don't think I have ever seen it done in a first person game before. It is both a blessing and a curse. It's a blessing because when it works, it works really well and gives a new depth to the game that would not have existed without it. It's a curse because it can be extremely fiddly and disorientating. Sometimes things just don't seem to work as well as they should and simple things turn into frustration inducing annoyances. It's a real shame too, since the system is *almost* good. Example: want to climb down and hang on the ledge? Forget it, something this simple is possibly the most frustrating thing you will ever do in this game.

This game also features a unique night-time experience where you must run, dodge and hide from powerful super-zombies during night time. Unlike the normal Z's, these ones chase you and can run just as fast as you can. When they catch you it's game over - so a race for the nearest safe-zone ensues. This part of the game really fills you with panicked adrenaline and mixes up the pace of the game. It is a welcome and interesting addition.

The (side) quests suffer from the same thing they did in Dead Island - fetchy and boring for the most part. There is one exception that I have found so far. In order to tell you about this I will just explain what happened to me:

reviewText:
A very fun and solid game. It's a wombo combo of Dead Island, Mirror's Edge, and the wooping Far Cry: an open world set with tons of things to do, parkour around the rooftops or whatever the hell you can find and climb, and find creative ways to kill your enemies. Of course, right off the bat the game is gorgeous looking, especially the detail on the zombies and what not. It's also worth mentioning what the mods will be capable of for this game.

Although I do recommend this game by a lot, I do not recommend going out at nightime if you do plan on playing.

I also recommend picking up small gas tanks. You'll know why.

CO-OP is also quite fun, and if you feel like tearing some zombies together, it works quite well.

Story had much more potential, especially if decision-making was implemented into the game.

reviewText:
At the end of the day, as much as one is inclined to, it is difficult to find fault with a game like Dying Light.

Aesthetically, the game is a pleaser. In terms of performance on the PC platform, save for the fps related issues on release week, Dying Light performs respectably even on a mediocre rig. On a high-end rig, Dying Light chugs along at the highest settings with nary a hiccup. As for its gameplay, the action in Dying Light is fast and fluid. Combat is flashy as well as impactful, and killing zombies has never felt more brutally satisfying. The parkour mechanic, which is your character‚Äôs main form of locomotion in Dying Light, is also somewhat intuitive, save for a few logical inconsistencies. If your gut tells you that a bridge‚Äôs truss is traversable to reach its top, you are unlikely to be wrong. Scaleable aspects of a building are very well-differentiated from those that you can‚Äôt interact with. Thus whether it is crisscrossing Harran‚Äôs rooftops, or climbing to the top of a clock tower to catch the setting sun, Dying Light‚Äôs parkour mechanic makes it both hassle-free and a pleasure to explore its vast and interesting setting. There is no mistake about it, Techland has done an admirable job here: Dying Light is one hell of a game to play, whether alone or in a group.

Unfortunately, Dying Light has about as much of a heart or soul as the cold and ruthless GRE boss that your character works for.  I could blame the game‚Äôs lack of spirit on its poor storyline, as many other critics have done. I could also blame it on the half-arsed supporting characters that the game seemingly throws at you by the dozen, only to then either arbitrarily kill them off or to leave their relationship with your character hanging by a thread and incomplete. Rather I am going to attribute it to Techland‚Äôs failure to make any of the interesting features, that it implements in a seemingly laundry-list like manner, into a mainstream component that properly defines Dying Light and what it stands for.

Take the game‚Äôs setting in Harran for example. Yes, Harran is a vast and spacious open-world in which players can explore to their hearts‚Äô content. Yes Harran is both beautiful, in a morbid kind of way, and immersive. Yet Techland barely utilizes it to further engage and immerse Dying Light‚Äôs players. There is a wafer-thin amount of dynamic events in Harran, which usually exists in the form of survivors fending off zombies, or Rais‚Äô goons sitting idly on top of one of the air-supply crates which the game sporadically generates.

Harran also remains the same dreary and worn out place that it was when your character first stumbled into it like the ‚Äòexperienced‚Äô secret operative that he is, until the moment you dispose of your main nemesis and complete the game‚Äôs main storyline. Converting one of its zone into a safehouse may result in you visually pushing or toppling a couple of shelves or cupboards over, as a form of barricading, but there is otherwise no obvious visual cues that suggest Harran is changing or evolving as a result of your character‚Äôs actions. Neither does its inhabitants become better off as you fulfil the usually tedious tasks that they set you out to do. An extreme example is the game‚Äôs escort missions, where completing one of them merely returns the relevant NPC that you successfully protected back to his or her starting spot, ready to offer you the same mission again. As a result, playing in Harran can occasionally provide a disconnected experience, one where you realize that nothing your character does ever truly matters.

On the other hand, do I think that Dying Light is a game worthy of your money, even at full-price? Yes it is. The game is extremely well-polished and has a good amount of content for you to sink your teeth into. Parkouring your way through the game‚Äôs numerous side missions is also an addictive experience. I can‚Äôt count the number of occasions where I had originally set out to spend 15 minutes on one of the game‚Äôs side mission, only to have those minutes turn into hours as I explore, craft, and decapitate or bash zombie heads in.

It‚Äôs most unfortunate that Dying Light‚Äôs absence of a heart and soul, as a result of Techland‚Äôs relative lack of ambition, means that it will remain a game that is a distance aways from being a truly great one. This in itself does not detract from the fact that Dying Light is through and through an entertaining game to play. And entertain you it most certainly will.

reviewText:
Well, Where to begin with Dying Light.

After finishing the main storyline with plenty of side quests that I missed, I can safely say that this game was quite something.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

I'm not quite sure where to start with this review so I'll just start with the good stuff first.

It holds good variety in weapons and zombies, As well as various human enemies, Both military and non-military. The parkour is, in my opinion, pretty smooth, Maybe not to Mirror's Edge standard but it gets the job done nicely. Combat feels very satisfying and well done, Especially with the dismemberment of body parts. Graphics aren't too bad, Even at a low resolution, The game still looked very pretty on my computer, though others may disagree. The variation between day and night offers a nice change in the gameplay, One minute you're a zombie killing badass, The next you're a wimpy baby hiding from corners and climbing rooftops as if your life depends on it, Because 9 times out of 10, it does.

A few very small but noticable features in the game add to it's charm, Such as the three seperate skill trees, Survivor, Agility and Power, Each having unique perks that help improve the way you play the game (If you're not too busy dropkicking Zomboids off the rooftops to notice them). The menu's are similar to Dead Island, So those who played that should instantly be used to it, Though it's easy for new people to understand. Certain NPC's in the game can offer some valuable loot and a weapon completely for free,  Crafting feels very well done with the different varieties of blueprints you can find throughout the world or earn through quests (Flaming, Electrifying Sledgehammers FTW!) And it's open world gameplay with two different areas to explore: The Slums, where you start the game off and play about 70% of the game, The other being The City, Where you travel to during the main storyline and has much, much bigger buildings.

I personally haven't played Multiplayer with any of my friends who also own the game but from the few random dudes who have joined my game whilst I play, I would say that the Multiplayer runs quite smoothly. As the host, It gives you plenty of oppertunities to set up challenges for you and your friends to complete, Such as kill the most zombies or find the most loot and whatever else the game decides. I do have a personal recommendation if you intend to go public online when you're playing so random people and friends can join you, TURN OFF ZOMBIE INVASION. If you don't want to be CONSTANTLY invaded by super zombies trying to munch your face off, Turn this off. If not, You'll most likely find yourself being invaded every 5 minutes with NO ONE to help you, You'll be left alone and have quite a disadvantage, Though if that's your kind of thing, Go right ahead.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Plenty of good stuff to say about this game, Now for the bad stuff...

The story isn't great. Pretty much throughout the entire thing, You can already see what will happen from miles away and most times they do. The characters aren't too interesting and some are completely forgettable, Even though this game tries at times to make you feel something for the characters and make you feel connected to them (I'm looking at you, Rahim.)

The game takes a little while to bring out the different enemy variations, Which mainly consists of you having to play through the main storyline before you even see mutated zombies in the world and even then, You rarely notice any or don't pay enough attention to notice them, the most I've seen is the normal snappy bitey zombies, Some Viral zombies which come when you make noise (The super fast ones in daylight) and the big hulking fellas with metal rebars usually standing around in one place.

And I cannot finish off this review without mentioning The Final Boss of the game, The psychopathic dude who has ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• you off, Killed your comrades and ultimately made your life terrible in this zombie apocalypse. It comes down to that final moment, you finally reach the top of his mighty tower after scratching and clawing your way past zomboids and virals and falling to the dirt many, many times. A cutscene comes along, You and your enemy face off and what do you know? QUICK TIME EVEEEEENT!!!!

You could see it coming a mile away, A God Damn Quick Time Event for the final boss. Please bear in mind that other bosses in the game that you fight, The Main Boss's Right Hand Man being just one of them, You fight all of those in the game normally, Dodging and leaping and slashing and dying a lot. But oh no, Not with this final boss, They treat you with a nice little QTE right at the end and you could EASILY see it coming a mile off. A dissapointing ending, In my opinion.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Well, If you could be bothered to read through all my rubbish, Welcome to the end! ~Confetti and Fanfare~

So, Final opinion on Dying Light.

Although it has a few faults in the game that can be noticed with ease and may annoy a lot of players, Especially that damn final boss, Does it make Dying Light a bad game? Not. At. All.

It's Fun, It's Satisfying and it certainly lived up to my personal expectations when I first heard about it and got excited to play it.

If you're a Zomboid fan, A Parkour Fan or you just like to slice dudes up and dropkick them from rooftops like a total boss, I HIGHLY recommend Dying Light to you. Some may argue about the asking price of this game but from what I've played and seen, I personally think it's worth it.

Dying Light has been, In my opinion, A great start to a new year of gaming, I only hope that developers can keep this up for the months to come.

Until Then, Catch ya later, Folks!

Good Night And Good Luck!

reviewText:
The Adventures of John Sinamoi
Having survived a nuke by hiding in a refrigerator, John parachutes back to earth only to find those dang zombies up to no good again! Johns voice may sound a bit different, ( a kiwi hit his throat while flying through the air) but he still knows how to kick some ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•. In Dead Island, you played a pansy who tripped on shoelaces and could barely step over a brick; but not John! Now Sinamoi can show you his running and climbing skills as well as tackling anything that gets in his way.

Even his mighty skills are put to the test however; common zombies tend to group up more (instead of 5 or so, you can get groups of 10 or even 20.) and the specials can present more of a threat. John also has the choice of going out at night to get bonus expierence and loot.

You can customize your Sinamoi adventures in a more varied way than in Dead Island. There are three different skill trees that level independantly; this gives the player more Sinamoi action and less time theory crafting!

For those who liked Dead Island but thought it was a bit too buggy and not enough Sinamoi, then I would definitely suggest this game (though maybe at a sale.) For those that didn't like it, then there isn't enough change to have you bother with it.

JOHN SINAMOI

reviewText:
Dying Light Co-op Review
First and foremost, this review will be concentrating on the co-op side of Dying Light.

A Quick note about solo playAs a single player game Dying Lights atmospheric tension and challenges are just what you would want from a survival horror game. The squalid and zombie infested environment of Dying Lights Harran somehow manages to retain a certain beauty and the  wonderfully crafted world draws you in making you want to explore every inch. The combat, weapon systems and movement are  beautifully balanced to offer players a challenge without being too tricky to master with a little practice. The night and day cycles require different approaches as night sees a clear advantage swing to the zombies. This game is more about being a  savvy player rather than all out hack and slash or bravely running away as both elements will be required equally, along with a healthy dose of stealth and cunning depending on the situation. There is plenty to keep you busy too with over 50 hours of game play. For the best experience set your gamma up correctly and play in the dark with headphones, it really ramps up the  tension and immerses you deeper into the game.

As with most games these days you get a bevy of unlockable skills which you will soon come to rely as you progress and wish you had from the start. However the best tool by far is the grappling hook as it makes moving across the map and escaping the undead really flow. Unfortunately, you will need to put in at least 10 hours of game play before you unlock it.

Coop - My Take on itThis is my review proper, the coop play of Dying Light and where my opinion seems to differ widely from everyone else. I will  say it now, I am not a fan of the co-op in this game. While some elements work others don't and at times it is more multiplayer PVP than it is coop. I increasingly found co-op annoying and more of a hindrance and an intrusion rather than a help. It's far from bad and it has its place, but, for the most part it is not what I would call true co-op play.

Dying Light supports drop-in/ drop-out co-op for up to four players. The entire campaign is playable in co-op, and there are special co-op challenges.

CombatOkay so you got me on this, (with the exception of Be The Zombie" element which I will come to shortly) co-op combat is actually that as you can't fight each other and can work together killing zombies. However

reviewText:
The concept is good. The gameplay is good, but there are several extremely lacking, and boring design-choices. I still recommend it, but not at full price, and not for vanilla gameplay. Here's my opinion. (it should be spoiler-free)

The game leans too much on the Casual gamers. The MC becomes more or less SUPER-HUMAN quite early to the point that the gameplay becomes boring as you can either flatten everything in your sight or outrun every possible threats.

During the day, normal enemies post little to no threat, too little in numbers with their minimum aggressiveness, and stupid AI. There are several special enemies, but they are not really a threat, as most of the time, you can easily spot them from further away without provoking them, as you won't find much 'distraction' from other normals.

Night can be overwhelming at first, but after a few hours, you will find that it is quite easy. You can't really die unless you clash right into enemies, or run in long flat route.

You will notice many inconsistencies during the game, making it feels like the developer changes some of their design-choices midway, but forget to make it consistent through the whole thing. (they did)

Hard Mode is still lacking the difficulty it deserved, still, a nice addition for vanilla.

COOP gameplay is a joke. The game puts 4 SUPER-HUMANS together, making the game much easier, and lost its charm quickly, as 4 of you slaughtering (bullying) through the hordes of 'punching bag-style' enemies.

However, there are difficulty MODS that will change that, and make the game fun to play, especially with friends. It can be a little glitchy at times, but it won't stop you from playing.

TL;DR The game is good, but can be easy, and boring fast as a result from design-choices. Get some difficulty mods, and friends to play with ;D

reviewText:
I'll simply start by saying that Dying Light is -- hands down -- the best open world game I've played in my entire gaming career. In fact, it's fast becoming one of my favorite all-time games (and I've been gaming since the '80s).

As opposed to others in its genre (Assassin's Creed, Sleeping Dogs, Red Dead Redemption, Skyrim, ...), this game does not propel you from one mission to the other, having you grab for fast travel at every opportunity. No, you'll be crawling through the streets or jumping across roofs to try to get to your next mission alive! The in-between is just as much fun -- if not more so -- than the actual missions.

Which is not to say that the story is bad, far from it. You'll find yourself engrossed in the unraveling story line, meeting interesting and colorful (and every now and then comical) characters, with voice acting well done ... finally!

Add on top of that a seamless parcour gameplay, four completely different parallel RPG-style skill trees, a crafting system that finds the perfect balance between having to search for new material and using awesome weaponry -- until they are broken and you either repair it or build something new --, fantastic mo-capped animations for monsters, a tense and exciting day-night cycle, and to top it all off -- the lush cherry on the delicious whipped cream -- an unbelievably stunning graphics engine.

Oh, and the zombies are sufficiently creepy and so very believable! This game has my heart pumping with fear, excitement, and relief dashing for the nearest safe zone while a viral or hunter is chasing me down. Something that hasn't happened ever since I played Thief in '98.

Another thing I need to mention: every other game I've played like this is only really exciting for the first couple of hours. After that, I rely on save games to get away with recklessness and, given enough tries, complete whatever task I'm undertaking. Not so with Dying Light. Death is not permanent and you'll respawn in the nearest safe zone, but you will lose plenty of survival skill points, making you fall behind on that skill tree. That's incentive enough to be careful and make for a continuously tense and exciting game.

Just one piece of advice, though: turn of the minimap and take your time to try to learn the layout of the city by heart. There are plenty of landmarks that help you find your way. This greatly improves on the immersion and gameplay.

Pro:
Beautifully hand-crafted open world. Not a single thing looks like a repeated pattern.
Perfect open world gameplay. The game is playable without a minimap (and much more exciting for it) and because of the danger around every corner, you don't constantly feel like you want to fast travel.
Stunningly beautiful graphics. Make sure you have a high-end machine for this.
Great story and characters. You feel empathic and enthralled within the first five minutes.
Intense zombie horror atmosphere. It's as close to the real thing as you can get.
Realistic skill point system. Gain skill points in Agility, Power and Survival, by jumping/running/climbing, fighting, and completing quests, respectively.
Diverse skill trees. Each skill tree has many interesting and useful skills, both passive and active. Choose your preferred style of play.
Engaging item crafting system. Unlike most other games where crafting is fun for the first few hours and then gets way too easy and overpowered, Dying Light continuously forces you to make new weapons and gear, because the more you use them, the more you wear them out.
Diverse weapons. Pimp your melee weapons by making them stronger, easier to handle, or more durable. Add electric, fire, poison or bleeding effects. Or use the very powerful firearms that kill your enemies with one shot (hopefully), but will attract many more with the noise it produces.
Con:
... I'll let you know when (if?) I see one.

reviewText:
Dying Light is a mostly fun zombie-slaying game that utilizes parkour. It's brought to you by the creators of the first Dead Island and Dead Island: Riptide, Techland. Dying Light outshines Dead Island greatly, even with its launch issues. It features better writing, a greater sense of verticality that works well with the parkour and grappling hook, skill trees that make progression feel more significant, graphic and enjoyable combat, a fearsome night, some bugs, and questionable design decisions that did not sit well with me.

The story has one main protagonist instead of a cast of four a la Dead Island. You play as Kyle Crane, an undercover GRE (Global Relief Effort) agent sent to recover a file lost within the city of Harran. As Crane, you bear witness to the insane brutality and sadness that affect the survivors of the devastated city. Dying Light managed to present an okay, passable story that did not make my eyes glaze over as if I were one of the undead. The main antagonist was crafted to be obviously evil and fond of diabolical plans which came off as cheesy or clich√© at times. The writing lacked the finesse to not be predictable. However, some of the side-quests were very well done with how they portrayed loss and grief. On the other hand, the game definitely could have done without the useless find x number of item side quests that served no purpose or told any stories.

Dying Light's world is generally fun to navigate due to the winning mixture of parkour and well used vertical space. Although, sometimes you will find yourself falling down and taking damage due to learning what can and cannot be grabbed, a feeling that's amplified with the use of the grappling hook. You will need to learn how to use its lock-on on ledges before channeling Just Cause's Rico Rodriguez since you can grapple onto most surfaces, including the ground. Unfortunately, Kyle Crane cannot use the grappling hook on zombies. The parkour keeps on improving as you level up the Agility tree and chain maneuvers. Do you want to vault off a zombie and dropkick another zombie into spikes or vault off a railing to drop two stories below, avoid damage by rolling, and then continue to run about? It feels like Mirror's Edge's lite with its own style, but no wall running.

The world of Dying Light uses height well. The first major area in the game is in a poorer part of Harran filled with shops, abandoned vehicles, cheap housing, incomplete skyscrapers, a large highway, a sweet bridge, radio towers, a coast, and open areas to run across. The second major area is dense with buildings which plays very well with the grappling hook and jumping around in general. I greatly enjoyed hopping between two story lampposts to cross a plaza or scrambling up buildings to avoid Volatiles during night. Yes, there are radio towers, but during those sequences I thought the game produced a nice sense of height as wind sounds and camera tilting worked to make me nervous. I think only three of them are part of the critical path for the story, so do not worry.

They did a good job with making the points in the skill trees feel significant. There are very few skills that have mundane percentage increases and focus more on adding more to the gameplay via new techniques or recipes. You can end up with throwing stars that can freeze zombies, a spinning attack, an upgraded slide to break knees, or the ability to squash the heads of enemies frolicking on the ground. Skill points greatly affect the way you move, fight, and items you can craft.

The combat has a slow start, but turns into a slaughterfest as strikes start cleaving enemies into two, horizontally and vertically. They could have balanced it better to make the beginning more impactful and prevent the p. I found a great amount of joy in using advanced abilities to destroy hordes of zombies and pesky humans. The humans tend to be much more dangerous when engaging them in melee, especially early in the game. However, you can easily dispatch them with molotovs or grenades if you do not have a firearm handy. I popped heads like watermelons, drop kicked zombies into various environmental hazards, lured enemies into traps, and much more. There should be enough gore in Dying Light for the zombie enthusiast. The zombies come with a bit of variety too. You have normal zombies (Biters), Virals (the runners), Goons, Volatiles (the scary ones), Toads, Bombers, Demolishers, Screamers, hazmat Biters with explosive gas tanks on their back, and Night Hunters if you allow pvp. You will not be killing Volatiles in the beginning. They have multiple attacks and need to be weakened before attacking them. Co-op makes them less scary once your group has decent weapons and support items available, but carelessness will still result death. Co-op is a fun and silly experience with occasional desync hiccups that result in weird physics on bodies.

The night in Dying Light creates an unfriendly environment filled with tension. The night makes zombies more aggressive, allows Volatiles to come out of their nests, and introduces a four level alert system. The more trouble you cause, the higher the alert level becomes causing many angry zombies to converge on your position. I would recommend carefully killing some regular zombies during the night because experience for both Agility and Power are doubled with a bonus to Survivor level as night ends. Co-op tends to trivialize the night experience if everyone is packing flares unless it is a level four alert. The grappling hook also makes night easier until you miss the ledge of a three story building during a chase. God help you if that happens.

This game had some issues upon release with many of them resolved. They are still working on additional issues. You can read through this thread to see a comprehensive list of different bugs: http://steamcommunity.com/app/239140/discussions/0/604941528488544773/ I personally experienced four bugs: a waypoint that wouldn't disappear from the map, a ledge on an optional radio tower that sent me out of bounds (I could swim back in), being unable to interact after killing enemies with a gun and then switching weapons (patched), and the inability to reach max Survivor level. Not bad with a system that did not meet minimum specs except for RAM.

There were some design choices that did not do the game justice here. The sound design for the guns felt flaccid because they fired as if they all had suppressors. Then the game had a few, annoying deaths that made me bitter. They tend to happen in this manner: you go into a room and a Bomber bursts through a door and kills you instantly or you open a door and are greeted by a Bomber or two. At one point in the game, they change the behavior of a hazmat zombie so that it runs toward you and detonates. That kind of design adds nothing to the gameplay or enjoyment of the game. Co-op can help mitigate those situations, but not always. Thankfully, the number of those incidents remains below ten. The game make use of too many camera effects with the long lasting water effect that blurs your screen for far too long irking me the most. There are no options available to turn those effects off. At this time, you will need to mod them out and a good place to start is http://www.nexusmods.com/dyinglight/ I know some people do not like those obnoxious effects or film grain. Weapon variety suffers from blunt weapons leaving the weapon pool at higher Survivor levels. Finally, the ending was mechanically disappointing and completely out of place.

Dying Light is not a perfect game. It has its flaws, but it is much, much better than Dead Island and is much closer to achieving that wonderful zombie slaying game I have always wanted. The improved movement adds so much to the game when it comes to combat and navigation. The drop kicks are fantastic.

reviewText:
So... After playing and beating the game I can say this game is definietly a good purchase depending on a couple things.
If you want a TL:DR check the botttom first thing out of the way if you have AMD DO NOT buy this game it is not optimized for it in the slightest wait for a patch if you are using amd and want to play this game. Despite what people say about there being fps issues and it not being optimized that is true for the most part but blown out of proportion if you turn your view distance down your fps is fine. Now that that is out of the way for the sake of my sanity im going to make a simple pros and cons list with some mentions in between. WARNING there will be some minor to medium story spoilers within this if you wish to skip these just watch out for when i have the spoiler warnings and read over it.

Pros
like dead island with parkour but in a good way
Parkour is fluid and doesnt feel glitchy
Has a decent story time I clocked in about 25 to 26 hours in my first playthrough (I have not done new game plus with my friends yet so that will probably add about another 20 hours minimum to the game)
Be the Zombie is a fun gamemode that is an excellent addition to the game
The graphics are pretty good especially at night the lighting effects on high are great.
Night time is actually scary even later in the game


Cons
Not optimized for AMD users in the slightest
Although I said i clocked in 25 hours for the story that is including be the zombie time and side missions. The story is disappointingly short if you only do the main story with a couple of side missions getting you maybe 6 to 7 hours.
The grappling hook makes it really easy to get away from the volitales (AKA the night creatures) that said it still can get intense in a high even star chase.
At the moment be the zombie matchmaking is broken and is hard to get in to a game making it where usually when you finally get in to a game unless someone was already in the game with the host doing co-op it will be a 1v1. Making it unless the human really knows what hes doing makes it a really easy win for the night hunter.



Side notes
The grappling hook to my surprise isnt something that has an infinite amount of uses you can use it two times then it has to recharge. I was worried when i saw it it would remove the parkour mechanic entirely which luckily it doesnt and if anything adds to it.
This isnt too big of an issue for me to count this as a con but the uv light can be buggy at times for both sides wether its you shined it at the hunter and it doesnt register or, as your pouncing a human they can somehow shine the light on you.
Finally something that i found cool myself is that when repairing a weapon you can see visually the metal or other materials you added to the weapon to repair it and weapons dont have infinite repairs meaning eventually the weapon wont be repairable anymore. This is a downside bieng your supe awesome legendary weapon will be inneffective eventually but also nice since it allows you to get somewhat variety in the weapons you use.


Tl:DR Dont get if your an AMD user otherwise its a good game overall with a great co-op/story experience.

reviewText:
RIght so, first and foremost, Dying Light is hands down the best co-op Zombie game I've ever played since Left4Dead 2, bar none. All those other Zombie genre games are cool and the gang and all that, but Dying Light imo beats all of them out in terms of everything EXCEPT for the competitve multiplayer aspect. Left4Dead 2 is still the best versus zombie modes I've played, however the co-op aspect, Dying Light absolutely slaughters any zombie game past and present imo.

Really fluid combat, amazing graphics, good plotline with a decent few twists, good voice acting (the main character is actually funny, especially on the mission where he has to harass people for money), lots of missions and side missions as well as competitions for co-op purposes. I also like how you can seamlessly join and leave games without the game pausing to load to let people in. The crafting system is much like Dead Island minus the requirement to be at crafting stations which is absolutely outstanding. The new user interface compared to Dead Island's interface is damn near a complete overhaul for the best; you can clearly see that they took the same general concept that they used in Dead Island and listened to their QA team and players who chimed in on how they liked to see it work and made it all come together like Voltron. ^^ The lock picking system is basically like Elder Scrolls: Skyrim (I didnt play the ones before Skyrim sorry~) which is a really easy to learn and probably the best lock-picking system I've ever seen in a game. Also, the in-game voip works exceptionally well -- but they need to add a push to talk feature. For the fear factor I can see them not having it (hearing your friends yell when the zombies go ham, egg and cheese on them at night is hilarious), its also equally annoying as Im not interested in hearing neckbeards in public games breath all heavy and ragged on the mic, have 15 year old Xbox Live players calling me the N word every 4 seconds or hear people speaking another language to someone in RL and completely disregarding what anyone is saying/doing in-game. hahah.  ^^

It seems like recently, very few games I've seen that are remotely based off a previous title or more have put together the missing pieces to form a much better game. By that I mean Farcry 4 seems like Farcry 3 and that's still good and all but I lost interest pretty quick as the plotline imo wasn't nearly as exciting as Farcry 3 was. Borderlands TPS is literally a reskinned Borderlands 2 with even crappier plotlines, boring content and terrible DLC's. Dying Light literally takes all the good things about Dead Island and merges it with features from other games to make this an outstanding new addition to any Zombie fan's gaming library. ^^ I'm looking forward to the DLC's, because let's face it, it can't be any worse than Borderlands The Pre-Sequel's DLC's so far, lol.

Imo the only thing that this game lacks is a female protagonist. I really liked how Dead Island allowed for multiple characters for the main storyline each with their own background. This game focuses solely on one guy and his clusterf*ck of a journey through the land of Immortui.

The only downside to the controls of this game is with the parkour system being in place along with the grapple hook you can accidently bug yourself out in quite a number of ways. There's a few safehouses that if you grapple into you can get stuck in this floating animation bug with your arm stuck out and the grapple hook floating forever until you take damage or relog. You also stay floating in the air and can fly unlimited during this glitch. Or if you get stuck on boxes your character gets the swimming animation. Both of these glitches in single player can be inconvenient, but in multiplayer make for extrmely hilarious situations hahaha. I'm sure they'll fix those in due time though. ^^

Oh and lastly, the grapple hook in this game is amazing! I had no idea it was even in the game until I unlocked it and I said :O when I did haha. I was more than happy with the parkour style movement in this game, so when I was able to basically become Bionic Commando AND kill Zombies at the same time, the top of my head exploded and confetti, cake, rainbows, unicorns, glitter and cupcakes came out! ^^ <3 Best day ever!!


TLDR:
Overall though I still give this game a 9.5 out of 10 even without a female protagonist character. (#femshep best <3)

Controls: 9/10 (You can't climb DOWN ladders or ledges without falling or leaping off the side and grappling something near or below you to break the fall. They gotta fix climbing down stuff ASAP imo.)
Combat: 10/10
Fun Factor: 10/10
Replayability: 9.5/10
Story: 8.5/10 (Mostly predictable but fun!)
Graphics: 10/10 (Like Farcry 3 when it was new, Dying Light looks amazing even on medium/low settings.)
Sound: 9/10 (A few rope/grapple hook sound loop glitches but Im sure they will fix them.)
Voice Acting: 8.5/10 (All children sound like adults and dying people on the ground sound 100% healthy. Past that, all the voice acting is really good, especially Rais, Crane, Jade, Rahim, Breckon and a few others.)
Overall: 9.5/10



Ty for reading! ^________________________^ <3

reviewText:
Overview
As a fan of all things zombie, I‚Äôve been looking forward to Dying Light for a while now. Overall, it‚Äôs a great game, and it has much going for it, but there are some odd design issues, a serious case of couriering (is that a word?) and just some attention-to-detail features that make me go, what?

I‚Äôve played for about 28 hours, I‚Äôm at 70% story completion, I‚Äôve finished 39 side missions, and I‚Äôve done six of the quarantine zones, as of the time of this review.

Want the TL:DR? Great game with great mechanics, a story that slowly devolves into a clich√©d mess, with some technical issues that shouldn‚Äôt really exist, and a few questionable design choices spread throughout. Still a great game. If I were to put it on a numbered scale, it‚Äôd get a seven out of ten.

The Good
+ Visuals are astounding, great atmospheric effects (such as debris floating around), explosions look terrific, zombies have great models. One touch I quite like is if a viral is in front of you and screams, their mouth actually opens and closes as it screams. Not a big deal, but adds a touch of realism.

+ Sound is also great, be it the music or effects. Connecting with a melee weapon gives a satisfying crunch, and guns sound like how guns should; firing off a shotgun blast results in a roar, not a pathetic tinny sound many games use for gun sounds.

+ The story, at least at the beginning. Sure, it‚Äôs rehashed (something happens, people become zombies), but it‚Äôs presented differently and keeps you intrigued for a bit, drawing you into wondering what happened.

+ The main mission. The primary goal of the game changes a few hours into the story, but the missions that you undertake for the main story are great, and they aren‚Äôt recycled very much.

+ Parkour. If Dying Light didn‚Äôt have a parkour element, it would definitely be your standard zombie exploration game. Not only does the parkour add an extra dimension, but it‚Äôs also done right; it doesn‚Äôt feel tacky or sloppy.

+ Progression and perks. There are three categories you improve in: Survivor, Agility, Power. Survivor points are gained by completing quests and quarantine zones, as well as challenges. Agility points are gained by just playing the game; climbing, jumping, strafing. Power points are gained by killing; melee, firearms, explosions, traps. There are 25 levels of each, and the perks are pretty nice. They act as a tree, and to unlock one, you‚Äôll have to unlock the first tier and go from there. It‚Äôs not too in-depth, but adds a nice touch.

+ Night mode. Nighttime adds an extra layer of trouble for you; it‚Äôs pitch black, and there are more dangerous zombies with heightened senses. It‚Äôs basically a stealth mode. However, completing quests, exploring or just being outside doubles what you earn for the period.

+ Random events. There are many random events. Air drops, which contain relief packages and some other goodies, are the big one for the first little bit. Get there quick enough, it‚Äôll be yours. Take your time, you may have to fight off some other humans for it. Take too long, and you‚Äôll lose the drop completely. There will be random survivors under attack who will reward you for helping them. Some people may turn into shopkeepers when you save them, giving you another location to buy and sell from. Some people might only be there to give some background on life in Harran before the outbreak. Maybe you‚Äôll help a group of survivors fight off some zombies, only to have them attack you afterwards. Lots can happen!

The Bad
- The story. As I said, the story starts off great, but after a couple of hours, it devolves into what has been seen hundreds of times before. I won‚Äôt give it away, but you can likely figure out what your goal changes to.

- Hit detection/clipping. I‚Äôve mainly seen this on the bigger guys with the huge rebars, but the hit detection is atrocious. He‚Äôll begin swinging, I‚Äôll dodge backwards completely out of range (even of the shockwave), yet I‚Äôll still get hit by it. Same for clipping. I might run behind a truck, yet the attack still manages to get me.

- First aid. To make a medkit, you need alcohol and gauze. Pretty realistic, as that will actually tend to wounds, although not restore you fully. Yet every single first aid/medical box you open will have gauze. Just gauze. No alcohol. A few hours in, I had maybe nine bottles of alcohol, yet I was up to 50 or so gauze. Just seems weird.

- Night mode. Yes, night mode is good (see The Good). But it‚Äôs not really that much more difficult. Your survivor sense will show an outline of the dangerous ones, and the minimap always shows their vision cone, so it‚Äôs not at all challenging to avoid them. You‚Äôll likely only run into them if you mistime a jump and fall hard and one‚Äôs nearby, or if you kill an enemy that makes a loud noise (hazmat guy by attacking the air compressor, or have one of the bloaters blow up).

- Technical issues. Even after the 1.2.1 patch, there are a few technical issues. While they obviously won‚Äôt apply to everyone, every few times I quit the game, it doesn‚Äôt exit properly. It drops me to the desktop, but the game is still running in task manager. I then have to end the task, and upon restarting the game, it begins in windowed mode, and I have to set it to full screen.

Aside from the odd exit issue, cutscenes sometimes freezes for a few seconds while the audio plays. If I wind up getting hit directly by the belching zombie‚Äôs green blob thing, the game freezes for a few seconds. Lowering view distance seems to help, but I shouldn‚Äôt have to lower that to compensate for poor optimization.

The Rest
+ Zombie models are pretty varied, with lots of different combinations. While you will run into reused models, they‚Äôll be few and far between.

- Godlike human enemies. Zombies, sure, they might take a little to knock down. But the humans are definitely of a godlike stature. There is no reason why, after burning for ten seconds from a Molotov cocktail, that they should survive a shot to the head from a pistol, and still require a few whacks to put down for good. That‚Äôs just ridiculous.

- Not much variation in the boxes or crates you run across. If you see a green, white or yellow box that looks dirty or rusty, it‚Äôll never require a lockpick. Likewise, if you come across a box that looks nice, or adorned with something, even if it‚Äôs in the dirtiest part of the slums, it‚Äôll require lockpicking.

- Most of the side quests are typical courier fare. Go talk to person, get item for them, return, get reward. This is a good 90% of the side quests, not including the quarantine missions. It‚Äôs like an MMO in the way they‚Äôve handled Crane being a courier.

- Protected survivors. Every now and then, you‚Äôll see a shield icon on your map; these are survivors who need escorting. They are all annoying, they don‚Äôt shut up, it‚Äôs never A to B, and they all run headfirst into every zombie without waiting for an escort. For example, a fisherman wants you to escort him to his secret fishing spot. But before that, you‚Äôll need to escort him to his rod. And listen to him talk about what a good deal it was. There‚Äôs also the American guy. I wanted to shoot his legs out and leave him for the zombies.

reviewText:
Dying Light, the second big title made by Techland after Dead Island, and it's a first person shooter, that has parkour going on with it, with zombies, in an open world setting, and it's good. I'd describe the game where it has Dead Island's zombies and nice combat, the open worldness and perspective of Far Cry, and the map design level and parkour of Assassin's Creed.

Starting with the graphics, they look really great, especially noticeable after the second half of the game. The animations and the lip-sync in cut-scenes or character interactions are noticeably not that good, and the graphical effects like blurry fog/water-drops are an inconvenience, and an annoyance that you have to put up with throughout the game.

The parkour controls are good and simple, and the melee combat controls are great and 'meaty', with the fire-arm controls being decent. The inventory management system isn't that great to interface with, at least not at first, which certainly could have been better.

The open world is fun and varied to play and parkour around in, with buildings to go through, and rooftops to hop on to. Filled with good amount of zombies, loot, and side missions to play with, and it's not cluttered with it, for example like Ubisoft games. The open world is also split into two big sandbox areas, the first one is nice and all, but the second one is where the beauty of the game is. A lot more nice to look at and to play around in, with how it is designed, more traversal and parkouring routes to have fun in, and just overall a better feeling to it.

The story isn't anything new, but at least they're trying to progress it in a way. Also, the main character you play as, he can kill, parkour and whatnot, and you'd expect him to have the ability to do those things because of who he is and how he is presented in the story, not just a random dude who got caught up in the mess, knowing how to do everything and be the best at it with no past experience. So what I'm saying is, Techland knows how to present a character, that makes sense, better than how Ubisoft presents them in their games.

The game is lengthy, with decently long campaign, and there being a lot of side quests that's, that's not that bad, you can do and finish. There's only one quick-time battle event in the game, it's short but still an annoyance to have it happen, made me think Really? Now you want to add a QTE?".

The coop is fun

reviewText:
Just finished the game today. Really enjoyed it. It is pretty similar to Dead Island with the biggest difference being the vertical aspect of movement that Dead Island lacked. Parkour is a lot of fun and is similar to Mirror's Edge. The world is huge and open. Just about every building can be entered and explored. Loot is everywhere. Combat is fun. Crafting is fun. The quests are fun. Challenges are fun. Movement is fun. Almost everything about this game is simply fun.

The storyline is really good as well and is lengthy. I logged 57 hours in the game and left out some of the stuff you can do although I feel confident that I covered almost all of it.

I really only had 2 complaints. The first is that my frame rate would dip when one of the spitting special zombies would hit me in the face with spit. Possibly correctable with tweaked settings and/or improved hardware. The other is the water blur" effect on the screen any time you get wet. It's super annoying and makes it nearly impossible to see anything for a good 5 seconds after you get out of the water.

All in all I really enjoyed this game. It's fun just to run/parkour around the city. It almost becomes an art form after you get the hang of it. Well done

reviewText:
It is a successor to the dead island franchise, or at least it feels like it.... if you like dead island 1 or 2, you will going to love this game, if you do not, beware.

That aside, this game is great.... it feels a jump to the moon in comparison with the dead island games.

Graphics are amazing.... you can't get more next gen than this right now.... very realistic and with amazing effects, which run just great on my laptop.... yes, laptop friendly, if you have a decent graphics card in it.

Gameplay is, like I said, very similar to dead island, scavanging for weapons, fixing them, upgrading them, leveling up and unlocking abilities, so the mechanics are basically the same, with cool weapons and abilities.

They also added pretty cool parkour moves to the game mechanics, and this makes it sooo amazing... you just can't get enough jumping and stomping zombies.

Story is a little weak, and the side missions feel like part of the story, but they distract you from advancing, to a point, that you can't tell when a story is side mission or storyline.
This is not the best zombie story out there, but it is good.

This game feel very long... I feel like I've played forever, between side missions and main story, and I'm far from halfway of the story... so it is worth the money, since you will be getting long hours, if you are completionist.

Zombies, violence, drugs and gore... if you are cool with that, I recommend it.

reviewText:
Take the best parts of Far Cry 3, Mirror's Edge, and your favorite zombie apocalypse game. Add in 4-player co-op, and invasions a la Dark Souls 2, and you've got a recipe for a great time.  I had heard about this game briefly back when it was announced and was so burned out on the zombie thing by then, I didn't think to give it a second look. When it was released, I remembered what I had heard, and after reading that it had co-op and invasions, decided I had to have it.

I jumped into the story really not having any clue what the game was about, apart from zombies, and while it's not the most exciting, original, or believable thing, it was enough to draw me into the game and get me on a path to where I cared enough about the characters I met early on to keep going. It pretty much stayed that way throughout. - nothing that I was super enthralled in, but enough to keep me going.

The big thing throughout the game is the day/night cycle and the difference between the two. After the tutorial and first major quest, you'll understand what I mean.  I don't want to ruin the fun.

The parkour-esque aspect of the game felt as good, if not better, than Mirror's Edge. Running, jumping, sliding, climbing, grappling, it's all really fluid and feels really well. Your character gets tired when it makes sense and, while there are some questionably inhuman feats, most of what you're able to do is believable apart from maybe some of the grappling stuff.

The combat feels great. Early on it can be a bit weird as you get used to the combat stamina mechanic and learn how much you can dish out before you need to take a breather, but overall it is very smooth and oddly satisfying when you bust open, chop off, or stomp on someone's/something's head.  The gunplay isn't bad either, it's about what you'd expect from something like this. There aren't but a few gun options in the game, most of which are pretty uniform throughout. If there are upgrades or options to them, I haven't found them yet.  That said, guns aren't usually the best idea anyway, as the noise can attract some pretty unfriendly folks.

The multiplayer is really satisfying. Co-op takes the singleplayer experience to a new level. It lets you drop in/out of friends games, and vice versa, and let's you help each other advance the story, create friendly competitions, or just go on zombie squashing rampages together.   If you enable Hunter Invasions, other players can invade your game as a super crazy Night Hunter" zombie and try and track down you and/or your buddies in a race to kill you before you can destroy all of its nests around town.  If you win
date: you get some xp and cool stuff
hoursPlayed: it gets stronger and stronger.\n\nTL;DR - If you like ANY of the games I mentioned in the first sentence
voteText: take a small look at this. If you like everything I mentioned
helpfulPercent: get this game. You probably won't be disappointed. I know I wasn't.  Good night. Good luck."
